title: brexit irish border backstop theresa may brady amendment deal vote
story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis:&nbspTheresa May will go to Brussels under instructions from MPs to seek a new solution to the Irish border issue. But does one exist? Ben Chu looks at the evidenceClick to followThe IndependentIs the prime minister looking for something that isn’t actually there?Theresa May is returning to Brussels to try to renegotiate the European Union withdrawal agreement to make it acceptable to a majority of MPs in the House of Commons.But what will she ask for?On Tuesday night almost all of her party’s MPs and&nbspa majority of the Commons voted in favour of an amendment put forward by the senior Tory backbencher Sir Graham Brady calling for the Irish backstop (the insurance clause that says the entire UK will remain in an EU customs union if there is no EU free trade deal struck that manages to avoid a hard border in Ireland) in the withdrawal agreement to be replaced with unspecified “alternative arrangements”.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialDowning Street’s logic is that, if the EU agrees&nbspto this, the agreement she brings back will finally make it through the Commons.But what might these alternative arrangements be? Even if the EU was prepared to reopen the withdrawal agreement, do they really exist?How badly could Brexit disrupt farming exports from Northern Ireland?The “Malthouse Compromise”, a proposal put together by Tory MPs from both wings of the party, refers to a “protocol” to replace the backstop in a document put out last month called “A better deal”. This was written by Shanker Singham of the Institute of Economic Affairs, a think tank with opaque funding.This protocol offers various technological and procedural measures – including, among other things, customs checks away from the border and a new regime of regulatory equivalence between the UK and EU – which would supposedly eliminate any new frictions on the Irish border as a result of the UK leaving the EU customs union and single market.But how credible is it?Dr Katy Hayward of Queen’s University Belfast says its provisions for policing standards and preventing smuggling would not be secure.Sam Lowe of the Centre for European Reform agrees that the document is not&nbspcredible in terms of policing.“Can you do it without physical infrastructure? Maybe. Can you do it without a significant uptick in ‘associated checks’? I don’t think so. Would it still constitute a border in many peoples’ minds and be disruptive? I think yes,” he says.In other words, if the Singham&nbspplan is the only alternative to the Irish backstop that Theresa May can offer to Brussels her renegotiation effort looks likely to be short and unsuccessful.Got an unanswered question about Brexit? story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis:&nbspFood retailers&nbsphave warned that some goods, such as fresh fruits and vegetables, will be in short supply if we leave with EU without a deal.&nbspBen Chapman&nbspconsiders the potential impactClick to followThe IndependentWill tomatoes be rationed?Of all the Brexit warnings coming from British businesses the one issued this week by food retailers was among the most alarming.&nbspSeveral of the industry’s biggest firms, including Sainsbury’s, Asda, Co-op, Waitrose and Lidl, said it is likely that a host of everyday products will begin disappearing from shelves if the UK leaves the EU without a trade deal.&nbspFor exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialBorder checks and tariffs will push up prices&nbspthere will be severe disruption to food supplies and supermarkets can only&nbspmitigate this by stockpiling to a limited extent, because warehouses are full and fresh food would simply perish anyway.The supermarkets concluded: “Government data suggest freight trade between Calais and Dover may reduce by 87 per cent against current levels as a result. For consumers, this will reduce the availability and shelf life of many products in our stores.”So will it be these words that prove to be empty in two months’ time, or British supermarket shelves?Created with Sketch. A police officer speaks with anti-Brexit protester Steve BrayPolice surround a pro-Brexit protester after he confronted a pro-European protester Conservative MP David Davies, wearing a gopro camera, speaks to anti-Brexit protester Steve BrayAnti-Brexit protester Steve Bray (left) and a pro-Brexit protester argue as they demonstrate outside the Houses of ParliamentPolice surround the pro-Brexit protester after he confronted Steve Bray, a pro-European protesterA leave supporter is spoken to by a police officer as he argues with a remain supporter, Steve Bray, outside ParliamentMPs in Parliament are to vote on Theresa May's Brexit deal next week after her December vote was called off in the face of a major defeatA leave supporter is spoken to by a police officer Police look on as anti-Brexit protesters demonstrate outside the Houses of Parliament. A police officer speaks with anti-Brexit protester Steve BrayPolice surround a pro-Brexit protester after he confronted a pro-European protester Conservative MP David Davies, wearing a gopro camera, speaks to anti-Brexit protester Steve BrayWe aren’t about to completely run out of food there is no need to massively stock up on tinned goods and head for the Anderson shelter. Still,&nbspit would be foolish not to listen to the concerns of a group of companies that between them sell about half the&nbspnation’s groceries.Their warning is backed up by evidence from several sources. Government figures show the UK produces 48.7 per cent of the food it eats and the proportion has been steadily declining. The rest is imported, with about two thirds of that coming from the EU.&nbspAdditional border checks on thousands of containers of food each year could mean significant delays which are a particular problem for fresh fruit and vegetables (the very items we are most dependent on imports for,&nbsp84 per cent of our fruit and 48 per cent of our vegetables&nbspnot being homegrown).&nbspEventually, supermarkets may be able to re-engineer their supply chains to restore the flow&nbspof fresh produce but many goods will undoubtedly be more expensive.Rising prices of fruit and vegetables will lead to 12,400 additional cardiovascular deaths between 2021 and 2030, research published in the British Medical Journal this week estimated.While some have argued that Brexit presents an opportunity to reduce&nbspour reliance on food imports and boost British farming, this cannot happen in the short term.And even if domestic production were&nbspto be ramped up drastically, UK climate conditions will not be suitable for all crops. We could heat thousands of greenhouses of course, but that raises significant environmental questions.There is a saying among optimists&nbspthat when life give you lemons, you should make lemonade. But what if there are no lemons, only turnips by the bucketload?Got an unanswered question about Brexit? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsEvent is not especially rare but 'very pretty', Nasa expert saysClick to followThe IndependentFrom left, planet Venus, the Moon and planet Jupiter are seen in the early morning sky photographed near Salgotarjan, 109 kms northeast of Budapest, HungaryCommuters have beem sharing their delight at the sight of Jupiter, Venus and the moon lined up in the early morning sky in a phenomenon known as a conjunction.The two planets were visible in the same section of sky on Thursday morning as the moon appeared to pass between them at about 6am.The same stunning line-up was visible to skygazers waiting on train platforms and elsewhere on Wednesday.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialVenus, because it is much closer to the sun, appears significantly brighter in the sky than Jupiter, the solar system’s biggest planet.Planetary conjunctions are relatively common events&nbspwith 14 expected this year, the Royal Astronomical Society’s Morgan Hollis told CNN.“Conjunctions aren’t that rare – they occur every few months,” according to Bill Cooke of Nasa. But, he added, “they’re very pretty”.In reality Jupiter and Venus are hundreds of millions of miles apart.Social media users posted a series of photographs of the phenomenon.Camera on my phone doesn't quite do it justice, said one.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. ensure no hard border in Ireland after Brexit.On Wednesday, Business Secretary Greg Clark said such technological solutions were not currently available. But Ms May’s spokesman said: “It is right that we do this work.“It is something that we have said we would be keen to take forward and work on with the EU.“It was set out in the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration that this was something both parties were committed to looking at as an alternative means of guaranteeing there would be no hard border in Northern Ireland.”The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. London, a march and rally in support of a second EU referendumThis week Ms May will seek support in the Commons for an attempt to go back to Brussels and renegotiate the deal she has already agreed with the EU, in particular seeking changes to the Irish backstop –&nbspthough European figures have ruled out any concessions.The poll carried out for HEPI by YouthSight found that backing for Labour among a weighted sample of more than 1,000 undergraduates was at just over half, with some 52 per cent saying they would vote for Mr Corbyn’s party.Corbyn faces Brexit revolt from MPs backing second referendumBut this was down by 10 percentage points on the same survey undertaken just over a year ago in December 2017, when 62 per cent said they would back Labour.Support for Mr Corbyn’s party was still significantly higher than its rivals – backing among students for the Conservatives fell one point, from 14 per cent to 13 per cent, and for the Lib Dems, it rose one point from 7 per cent to 8&nbspper cent.But the sizeable fall will not go unnoticed for a party that prides itself on representing the views of young people looking for a better future.This could leave Corbyn unable to guarantee the student vote to the same levels which boosted his result in the last general electionAt the same time the poll showed that students had increasingly strong feelings on Brexit and the need for the country to have a people’s vote to determine its path – less&nbspthan half of those questioned, some 43 per cent, were old enough to vote at the last referendum in 2016.The survey showed that 69 per cent of the group now backed giving the British public a Final Say on the outcome of Brexit, compared to 62 per cent who wanted a new vote in December 2017.Rachel Hewitt, director of policy and advocacy at HEPI, said: “While students generally continue to be both pro-Remain and supportive of the Labour Party, these results suggest Labour’s current position over Brexit may have cost them some support among students.“This could leave Corbyn unable to guarantee the student vote to the same levels which boosted his result in the last general election.”The Independent’s campaign for a Final Say referendum has been backed by the National Union of Students and more than 1.1 million&nbsppeople having signed the petition.NUS vice president Amatey Doku said the findings reflect the fact that students overwhelmingly voted for Remain in 2016&nbspand continue to be in favour of staying in the EU by a large margin.Brexiteers angry over electoral watchdog plan for prosecution powersMinister fails to totally rule out martial law after no-deal BrexitMinisters say no-deal must stay ahead of commons battle to kill it offHe said: “Any party which enables Brexit risks losing support from students, as this report shows.“That’s why if politicians want our support, they must represent us during this most critical of moments,&nbspthe ripples of which will be felt most keenly by my generation. The best way to do this is to support a people’s vote on the Brexit deal, and to truly give us a final say.”The fall in student support for Labour could be explained by several different reasons, but the concurrent rise in support for a new vote just as Mr Corbyn’s own MPs accuse him of prevarication over the issue is stark.At an event on the steps of parliament last week Labour and Tory MPs announced they would not table a cross-party amendment for a second referendum because it stood no chance of passing the Commons without Mr Corbyn’s support.Created with Sketch.Final Say petition we know that the majority of Labour voters, supporters and members want a final say on any Brexit deal.“Yet at a time when Labour should be championing a people’s vote, the leadership avoids answering that call.”She added: “There are millions of young people in our country that supported the Labour Party at the last general election. Over two million of them were under the age of 18 in 2016. They would today now have a vote. And so many whom I speak to cannot understand why Labour is standing in the way of the younger generation having a say on this.”Three of Mr Corbyn’s MPs later moved in parliament to redraft his strategy, so it ties Labour unambiguously to giving Britain a new referendum.The leader has already submitted the Labour Party’s own amendment setting out how he thinks the country should proceed, but it disappointed many backers of the People’s Vote campaign because it failed to fully commit the party to backing a new referendum.Mr Corbyn’s approach would require ministers to find time for MPs only to “consider and vote on options” including renegotiating the withdrawal agreement and also then “legislating to hold a public vote” on any deal that successfully passes through the Commons.The Labour Party has been contacted for comment.HEPI sponsored Wave 5 of the HEPIYouthSight Monitor, which was answered by 1,048 full-time undergraduate students and undertaken between 4-8&nbspJanuary. SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the options'No-one is saying this isn't going to be very challenging'Click to followIndy PoliticsJeremy Hunt has said&nbspBrexit could be delayed as&nbspthe government may need extra time to pass key legislation if Theresa May can agree a&nbspdeal&nbspat the eleventh hour.The foreign secretary admitted that a&nbsptechnical delay to the article 50 process could be necessary to prepare for Britain's exit from the EU, which is legally due to take place on March 29.MPs ordered the prime minister to go back to Brussels to renegotiate a key part of her Brexit deal after her plan was resoundingly defeated in the Commons earlier this month.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialBut despite the Tory truce, Ms May faces an uphill battle to convince the EU to reopen the withdrawal agreement, with European leaders lining up to rebuff her efforts.Tory Brexit truce crumbles as Theresa May accused of ‘stupid mistake’Asked about Britain's exit date, Mr Hunt&nbsptold the&nbspToday programme: I think that depends on how long this process takes.I think it is true that if we ended up approving a deal in the days before&nbsp29&nbspMarch then we might need some extra time to pass critical legislation. But if we are able to make progress sooner then that might not be necessary.We can't know at this stage exactly which of those scenarios would happen.His comments mark the growing concern among ministers to pass the necessary legislation before exit day, amid reports that February recess could be cancelled to give Ms May more time to win over the EU.Mr Hunt said a solution had not been properly worked up to replace the&nbspIrish backstop - which aims to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland.&nbspMPs backed a bit to&nbspreplace it&nbspwith alternative arrangements in a series of crunch votes on Tuesday.He said it was difficult to know if negotiations would run to the end of March, but added: Whereas a week ago none of us really knew whether this was going to be possible, we are now in a situation where it clearly is possible.There are lots and lots of hurdles -&nbspno-one is saying this isn't going to be very challenging -&nbspbut we do now have a consensus in parliament.We can use that consensus&nbspproviding we can meet these concerns, very reasonable concerns from our friends in Ireland about not having a hard border, concerns in the EU about access to the single market.Providing we can do that, which I think we can, then I think there is a way through.However his Austrian counterpart Karin Kneissl said it would be very difficult for the Brexit timeframe to be extended and warned that Britain could be heading for a no-deal exit.She said: According to the Article 50 procedures, the deadline is 29 March,&nbspso there is a time pressure because what couldn't be reached by negotiation over the last years, it's very difficult to imagine that there can be a tremendous breakthrough - a magic solution - in the next few days in order also to have this ratified in due time for the remaining EU members.Created with Sketch. story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeJoin us? Subscribe  registerJoin us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsFollow live updates from Westminster&nbspClick to followIndy PoliticsBrexit could be delayed as the government needs extra time to pass key leglislation, Jeremy Hunt has warned.&nbspThe foreign secretary said that a techincal delay to Article 50 may be required&nbsp- as a new study found that Theresa May's government was&nbspnot prepared for the consequences&nbspof leaving the&nbspEuropean Union without a deal.MPs ordered the prime minister to go back to Brussels to renegotiate a key part of her Brexit deal after her plan convincingly rejected by the&nbspHouse of Commons&nbspearlier this month.&nbspFor exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialJeremy Hunt warns the government may need 'extra time' to pass Brexit legislationParliamentary recess cancelled to solve Brexit chaosTheresa May accused of making 'stupid mistake' in EU talks&nbspMs Leadsom hit back at Mr Wishart accusing him of being the one in denial after she had read reports he did not want a second EU referendum because it might harm the chances of a second independence referendum.&nbspI would suggest the Scottish nationalists in this place are in denial over the result of the Scottish independence referendum.&nbspNot only that but he is also a pessimist and is already setting out how Government attempts will fail, which is deeply disappointing.Pete Wishart, the SNP shadow Commons leader, has also responded to the announcement and accused the Government of denialism over the parliamentary timetable.There's a word for the current condition, denialism - a person's choice to deny reality as a way to avoid the psychologically uncomfortable truth.Nothing could better sum up these unicorn-chasing Tories and the way they could interpret 'no, we will not renegotiate the political agreement' into 'yes, we will give you everything the member for North East Somerset wants'.It's denialism madness but at some point the hard reality will have to catch up with this Government, so can the Leader of the House explain what happens when the Prime Minister inevitably comes back with nothing?Can she explain exactly what we will be doing for that week given recess is to be lost?Valerie Vaz, shadow leader of the Commons, has criticised the decision to cancel recess, saying the government is staggering from one week to the next.I cannot possibly imagine what MPs are going through with this announcement.Can the leader of the House please say ... what provision will be given to MPs for their children?It can't be right that MPs have to support their children in that way without the Government stepping in and providing provision for it.More than 4,500 people slept rough in England last year, according to the new statistics released by the government.&nbsp&nbspIn response to the new statistic,&nbspSian Berry AM, co-leader of the Green Party, said:Rough sleeping is not falling anywhere near far or fast enough. It is shameful that in a nation as rich as the UK thousands are still facing freezing temperatures on the streets. With the right political will there is action we can take right now to give people shelter, and I urge the Government and local authorities to consider measures like opening up Britain’s many empty buildings.In the longer term we need to see an end to policies like Universal Credit and benefit sanctions which push people into poverty, and real commitment to policies which help deal with the causes of homelessness so no one is forced to sleep rough in the first place.”Ms Leadsom told MPs:The House will know that recess dates are always announced subject to the process of business.In this unique session of Parliament and in light of the significant decisions taken by the House this week, it is only right that I give the House notice that there are currently no plans to bring forward a motion to agree dates for the February recess, and the House may therefore need to continue to sit to make progress on the key business before the House.I realise that this is short notice for colleagues and House staff, but I do think our constituents would expect that the House is able to continue to make progress at this important time.&nbspOur Associate Editor, Sean O'Grady has done a video on how to Brexit proof of your life - give it a watch!Continuing on Mr Hunt said:&nbsp&nbsp“There are lots of things that we can consider. I'm not expecting a decision to be made this afternoon. But one of the things that the EU often does in these circumstances is put sanctions on iniduals who are responsible for some of the worst things that can happen. And the fact is that the elections that were held last year were not free and fair. They were not legitimate. We have made a very clear request to Nicolas Maduro to announce elections within eight days. So if he does not, we need to do something to increase the pressure to show that we mean what we say and we are not alone – this is Spain, France, Germany, many other countries, who have equally strong views as the United Kingdom. We are not considering sanctions against the whole country because there is a humanitarian situation and we wouldn't want to make the situation even worse. But targeted sanctions against the kleptocrats who have enriched themselves on the back of the rest of the population who are very poor, that is something I think can be effective.”Speaking to the BBC this morning&nbspon the situation in Venezuela, Jeremy Hunt said:&nbsp“When I spoke to Juan Guaido yesterday, I said to him that many people in the United Kingdom salute his courage and bravery for standing up for institutions in Venezuela. It is not for the UK to decide the outcome of what happens in Venezuela, that is for the people of Venezuela. Mr Guaido was very clear - he wanted us to put pressure on Nicolas Maduro, because they need change. &nbspThe elections were not legitimate, there was vote rigging on an unprecedented scale. Opposition parties were banned and we have a country whose GDP has nearly halved. People are in desperate straits. And what I want us to do is to put every pressure on Maduro and I'm urging EU foreign ministers to do exactly the same when I meet them this afternoon so that we do have free and fair elections and we give the people of Venezuela a fresh chance to start again.&nbspTheresa May spoke to European Council president Donald Tusk yesterday evening in what was described as an open and frank conversation, according to reports from Brussels.Afterwards, he tweeted: The EU position is clear and consistent. The withdrawal agreement is not open for renegotiation.The CBI said its study showed that spending on buildings, machinery and training are expected to be lower this year.Alpesh Paleja, CBI principal economist, said: Uncertainty in the domestic and global trading environment is clearly hitting manufacturing SMEs hard, with sentiment falling, concerns over political and economic conditions abroad spiking and investment plans still well down on the past year.To give the UK's SME manufacturers some much-needed certainty, it is crucial that politicians now work together to break the&nbspBrexit&nbspdeadlock.Smaller manufacturing firms expect only a slight increase in output in the coming months, while orders are set to be flat, a new report suggests.A survey of almost 300 small to medium sized firms (SME) in the sector indicated that optimism is falling and investment intentions for the coming year are weak.Jeremy Hunt was on Radio 4 this morning - here is a clip of what he had to say:&nbsp&nbspPlease allow a moment for the live blog to loadAccording to reports, the prime minister is now offering to provide additional investment for deprived areas that supported Leave in an attempt to secure the backing of potential Labour rebels ahead of any further votes on her&nbspBrexit&nbspwithdrawal agreement.Estimates suggest that Ms May requires at least 20 Labour MPs to support her deal.The promise of local investment could include spending on former mining communities as Ms May searches for a parliamentary majority, The Times reported.The plea comes as the scheduled date for the UK's withdrawal from the&nbspEU - 29 March - draws ever closer and the prospect of&nbspno-deal&nbspexit appears to grow&nbspincreasingly likely given Brussels refusal so far&nbspto reopen&nbspnegotiations on Ms May's rejected agreement.Last month the government announced it was accelerating&nbspno-deal Brexit&nbsppreparations and pledged an extra £2bn&nbspof funding but&nbspexperts at the Institute for Government (IFG) believe the UK is “not ready for no-deal”.&nbsp“The disruption from no-deal - simply from the lack of preparation - would be extremely damaging,” Bronwen Maddox, IFG’s director, told the BBC.&nbspIt cannot be dismissed as a mere blip.The think tank predicted that in eight out of 11 broad policy areas, including health and borders, the government would be unable to avoid some major negative impacts.Created with Sketch.Brexit so far: in pictures Show all 37Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Boris Johnson MP, Labour MP Gisela Stuart and UKIP MP Douglas Carswell address the people of Stafford in Market Square during the Vote Leave Brexit Battle Bus tour on 17 May 2016. projects could be 'hurt'&nbspif the government fails to 'plug the funding gap'Click to followIndy PoliticsThe UK lost more than €5bn&nbsp(£4.5bn) in infrastructure funding in a year as&nbsplending from the EU collapsed following the Brexit vote, a powerful Lords committee has said.Peers warned that major infrastructure projects would be hurt further&nbspif the government fails to&nbspplug the funding gap&nbspwhen Britain loses access to the&nbspEuropean Investment Bank (EIB) after Brexit, as ministers have relied on the EIB to fund major projects such as Crossrail and Manchester's tram extension.Brexit has already had a material effect on the UK's relationship with the EIB, which lent €7bn&nbspto 54 projects in 2016, compared to €1.8bn&nbspto 12 projects in 2017&nbspand&nbsp€932m&nbspto 10 projects last year, according to a new report by the Lords EU Financial Affairs Sub-Committee.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just with the EIB, which has contributed more than €118bn to UK projects in the last 45 years, ranging from&nbspthe London Overground to roads in Scotland, as well as major water and sewerage British economy, and in 2015 accounted for a third of total funding of UK infrastructure projects.The committee argued&nbspthat Britain should give swift and serious consideration to&nbspcreating a state-backed infrastructure bank to replace funding the country will lose.Baroness Falkner of Margravine, who chairs the committee, said: “For the last 45 years the UK has relied on the European Investment Bank to invest in all manner of vital infrastructure projects such as Crossrail, London’s ‘Super Sewer', the expansion of Manchester’s tram network and Scotland’s Beatrice offshore windfarm.“The UK’s infrastructure, and the industries that depend on infrastructure spending, will be hurt if the government does not quickly find a way of plugging the funding gap that will be also urged Ms May&nbspto come clean about why the government is not claiming Britain's share of €7.6bn&nbspfrom the EIB as part of its Brexit plans.Under the terms of Ms May's Brexit deal, the UK will receive the €3.5bn&nbspof capital it has paid into the EIB but it will not receive any share of the bank's profits, which the committee says could amount to €7.6bn.Responding to the report, a Treasury spokesperson said: “As we leave the EU, we will get every penny of the more than £3bn we put into the European Investment Bank back to invest in UK infrastructure. As recently as January 2017, annual house price growth was running at 4.3 per cent.Across the UK, the average house price now stands at £211,966, just £210 more than a year ago.For exclusive articles, events and an advertising-free read for just Start your free trialWith an Independent Minds subscription for just Start your free trialWithout the ads – for justStart your free trialA no-deal Brexit would see house prices slump a further 5 per cent in 2019, according to predictions from Howard Archer, chief economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club.Conversely, if a deal is agreed by March, prices could rise by 2 per cent, Mr Archer said.Created with Sketch. A girl looks at her phone and smokes, framed against a line-up of antiquated postcard features of Britain. She’s the most authentic part of the scene, however, a glimpse of modern Britain, while the red phone box belongs to the pastI walk through a field by the industrial estate where several horses live chained to the ground. They feed on thinning grass. The Transporter Bridge lies in the background: an emblem of movement and motion and crossing ides, like a cruel joke played on the animals, stuck and fixed and staticThe first second of 2019, welcomed with with a kiss, a hug, with stares and smiles, with a shot thrown down a throat, with phones and photos and forgettingShoes hang from lines of communication, sagging between houses, pulling down on the words and silences that somehow run through these black wires. It reminded me of the view from my bedroom window in PolandA queue to keep going, into the night, further into 2019 before sleeping. Vape rises distinctly, a new sight on the street in the last few years, bringing atmospheric emissions to the image. There’s sweat and purpose and promiseI’m struck by this naming and shaming, by the identification of supposed disloyalty, clearly marking the public space of the city for all to see, whether they care or not, whether they know or notA view from inside the Market Hall, looking out, onto another person sitting on the street and another person faced with the experience of walking by. Both lower their heads, as if in acknowledgement of the difficulty of the situationI walk to the end of a long jetty by the marina. Fisherman stand at the furthest tip, waiting for a bite, looking to the horizon where faint puffs of smoke appear and vanish from factories further down the east coastDwelling spaces of the dead and the living, closer than usual, occupying the same public space, both observable in one view, the burial ground of the local church acting as a garden for the housing estate behindA walk by the River Wear is comically framed from the Wearmouth Bridge, a view unavailable to the couple, who probably have no idea they’re walking into shot. This follows a subdued December, when price growth slowed to 0.5 per cent.“Indicators of housing market activity, such as the number of property transactions and the number of mortgages approved for house purchase, have remained broadly stable in recent months, but forward-looking indicators had suggested some softening was likely.Brexit uncertainty will push rents up faster than house prices by 2023The big Brexit forecast: what will happen to house prices in 2019?UK house prices growing at slowest pace in five years“In particular, measures of consumer confidence weakened in December and surveyors reported a further fall in new buyer inquiries towards the end of 2018.“While the number of properties coming on to the market also slowed, this doesn't appear to have been enough to prevent a modest shift in the balance of demand and supply in favour of buyers in recent months.”Mr Gardner said the uncertain economy is likely to be acting as a drag on the housing market, despite strong&nbspemployment figures,&nbspwage growth and low interest rates.He continued: “Near-term prospects will be heavily dependent on how quickly this uncertainty lifts, but ultimately the outlook for the housing market and house prices will be determined by the performance of the wider economy - especially the labour market.Howard Archer, of the EY Item Club said: “If Brexit is delayed, ongoing uncertainty is likely to weigh down on the housing market and could well see house prices stagnate or fall slightly.”Samuel Tombs, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said: “The uncertainty created by Brexit largely is responsible for the further decline in year-over-year growth in house prices to near-zero, from a broadly stable rate of about 2 per cent&nbspin the 18 months before November.”Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: john bercow out of parliament tories replace him
story: Today the chairman of the Tory Buckingham association is meeting the Conservative party’s national head of candidate selection Gareth Fox to find a suitable figure to fight the seat.He wants the party to start advertising the position from today.The Speaker has stood unopposed in his Buckingham seat since standing down as a Tory MP in  to take the neutral role of Speaker.But the Tories are hoping he will quit before the next election to free up the seat.The move will put pressure on Mr Bercow amid the outrage over claims he is helping Remainer MPs thwart Brexit in the Commons.When he was elected in  Mr Bercow had pledged to only serve until  but has cited the uncertainty over Brexit to justy staying on.It was understood he would only extend his tenure until June this year but Tories now fear he will use the deepening Brexit crisis to cling on longer and even beyond the next General Electiona snap vote is called.But that would be the fourth General Election in a row at which the Buckingham seat is left uncontested.Buckingham Tory association chairman Cllr Clive Harriss said anger was rising among constituents over their lack of a choice for MP at elections.He said the party would traditionally only start looking for a new candidate when the Speaker stands down.But he told The Sun: “We’ve started to put feelers out with a view we’ll have someone in place soan election is calledhe decides not to stand we’ll have someone in place to fight the seat in the normal way.“I’ll be talking to central office on Friday to make sure they advertise the position.”However he admitted the party has “absolutely no influence” over when Mr Bercow decides to stand down.Mr Harriss added: “We don’t know what’s going to happenthere is a General Election.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: molly russell social media blame
story: Vulnerable Molly Russell faced a flood of self-harm images on Instagram and Pinterest — helping drive her to suicide.The sites haven’t done enough to stop a repeat of this tragedy.And the power of the web giants is only growing. Last week, Facebook revealed plans to merge Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger into the world’s largest social network.Enough. We need action now.So well done Matt Hancock for threatening the nuclear option. He warns companies could be shut downthey continue to fuel a suicide epidemic.Britain must be a world leader in holding the tech Goliaths to account.No more kids should suffer Molly’s fate.MARTIAL law  Come off it.Claims that Britain will need military intervention in a No Deal Brexit are the most ridiculous fear-mongering yet.No Deal would be a challenge — but Britain would get through it and thrive.Panicked civil servants should listen to the Queen. As Her Majesty said, seeking common ground will take us far.Because evenNo Deal isn’t ideal, it must stay on the table.When Theresa May heads back to Brussels, the EU need to know we’re serious about walking awaythey don’t fix the ridiculous backstop.That’s why Yvette Cooper’s parliamentary power grab is so dangerous.If MPs delay Brexit fearing No Deal, Britain’s hand will be weaker, making a second referendum a real danger.It’s also worrying that Mrs May told allies she could never go for No Deal.Stand firm, Prime Minister — and don’t crumble to the prophets of doom.BOSSES at tax-dodging firms like Starbucks should read of Britain’s biggest taxpayers — and hang their heads in shame.Some firms will go to any s to slash their tax bills. But there are dozens of patriotic tycoons who shell out nine-figure sums to the state every year.James Dyson — a hate figure for the left over Brexit — paid £million last year, enough to fund , nurses.That’s  TIMES the size of Amazon’s UK tax payment.Entrepreneurs who give back to society represent the best of British.RACISM has no place in football.Bigotry reared its head at the weekend as Millwall fans chanted vile slogans during their game against Everton.In Italy, clubs are forced to play behind closed doorstheir fans spout racist bile at players or rival supporters.Let’s do the same here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. Picture research: Alfie Snelling.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “At the  Olympics, what birds were first released as a symbol of peace ” Georgina: “Eagle.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “What is the name of the monument in Trafalgar Square built in ­honour of Admiral Horatio Nelson ”Gemma: “Pass.”Ben Shephard: “Which British comedian ­presented the television programme Backchat with his father Michael ”Linda: “Jasper Carrott.”And Ben Shephard: “The Tartan Army is the nickname for fans of which national football team ” Najam: “Newcastle United.”Najam. A word . . .ITV’s The Paras: Men Of War, evenit needed three more episodes and better editing.BBC’s The Last Survivors. Tom Jones singing Cry To Me, with the talented Bethzienna Williams, on The Voice.The sudden, joyful NTA realisation the old bald bloke with the white beard in row A was Tim Lovejoy.And Celebrity Coach Trip guide Brendan Sheerin telling Jedward, Charlotte Crosby, Roxanne Pallett et al: “Today, you’re all going to a donkey sanctuary.” Well it’s about time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick clegg job fix facebook molly russell
story: The former Deputy Prime Minister, last seen being booted out by the voters of Sheffield Hallam, has re-emerged as Facebook’s Mr Fixit — the man tasked by its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, with rescuing the reputation of the embattled internet firm.Having claimed that “I actually find the messianic Calornian new-worldy-touchy-feely culture of Facebook a little grating”, Sir Nick has duly installed himself in a £million mansion near San Francisco, ready to offer his expertise.Some people have been puzzled about why the world’s most powerful social media company, owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, would recruit a man whose main brush with online fame was an autotuned video of him apologising for betraying the public over tuition fees.In fact, Clegg and Zuckerberg are a match made in heaven. Both are powered by an inexorable sense of self-righteousness. And both have an awful lot of experience of saying sorry.The most recent example came when Sir Nick appeared on the BBC in the wake of the furore over the death of -year-old Molly Russell.It turned out, after she was found dead in her bedroom in December , that she had been viewing material online relating to depression, self-harm and suicide — material which was shockingly easy to find.As her father Ian Russell put it bluntly: “Instagram helped kill my daughter.”Sir Nick, to his credit, said all the right things about how the firm was determined to do more. But he also made the striking claim that it is sometimes better for Facebook and Instagram to keep suicide images online, because it helps other vulnerable young people get support.This after The Sun, on Saturday, found and flagged up multiple images appearing to normalise and even romanticise suicide, all within a few clicks. Many remained published for days, and a Facebook spokesman claimed they could be beneficial to users battling mental health issues.Sir Nick says the firm is following the advice from leading experts and charities. And it may well be doing the right thing. But this is the latest example of Facebook — and other social media giants in general — only acting to tackle a problem once it becomes impossible not to.Over the past decade, social media has come to dominate our lives. The latest research from Ofcom shows internet use rocketing among children and teenagers, with friendships and social lives increasingly run through screens and phones.And it is now clear that this great move online has been accompanied, for our children, by a staggering increase in mental health problems.The situation is particularly alarming when it comes to young women. The latest NHS data found that one in four of those aged  to  report having a mental health disorder — twice the rate among boys.In  alone, one in five US girls aged between  and  suffered a major depressive episode — one in five! Suicide rates for teenage girls, according to academic Jonathan Haidt, have risen by  per cent in the US and  per cent in the UK in a decade.This isn’t just about what happens on the internet. Those having problems online often tend to be experiencing problems offline too, such as bullying, harassment or broken families.More broadly, Haidt believes the “snowflake” phenomenon reflects that “helicopter parenting” leaves children less prepared to cope with shocks and dficulty. But the internet, and social media, are very clearly intensying those problems. And the big tech firms are still playing catch-up.The traditional argument from Silicon Valley is that it’s not their job to regulate human behaviour. They add that eventhey wanted to, there is simply too much out there.They are doing their best to crack down on inappropriate content, but it’s like trying to stem the tide. Behind the scenes — they insist — thousands of people are working day and night to detect and delete messages promoting terrorism, hatred, Holocaust denial and self-harm.But this argument just doesn’t wash. It’s very clear that, in the interests of their bottom lines, many of the big social media firms have long failed to put enough resources into detecting damaging content.Researchers have shown, for example, how following the recommended links from reputable YouTube content can lead to a carnival of horrors. News reports that segue into crackpot conspiracy theories and videos for toddlers that give way to horrendous scenes of a bloodied Minnie Mouse trapped in an escalator.Every day brings new horror stories, such as rival fans of royals Kate and Meghan using the Kensington Palace Instagram to send death threats to each other. Increasingly, online hate is triggering real-le violence. The slaughter of the Rohingya Muslims in Burma was, The New York Times said, “a genocide incited on Facebook”.Part of the reason that Zuckerberg has hired Clegg is to put his house in order. title: eu backstop brexit nonsense
story: Will Eurocrats cause needless ­disruption just to make a point  Would they rather see all sides suffer than watch a post-EU Britain succeed If so, what would it say about the ­organisation we are leaving Let’s take a moment to recap.Immediately after the referendum, EU officials declared they would not talk to Britain about a long-term relationship until we first agreed withdrawal terms, including a “orce payment”, rights for EU citizens and the Irish border.Britain foolishly agreed. It was ­particularly silly to discuss Ireland before the main trade talks, since the obvious way to prevent a hard border on the island is through a deep and ­comprehensive trade agreement between the UK and the EU as a whole.That, though, would have given Ireland a strong incentive to get the best possible terms for the UK, and for itself.So instead, at the end of , the EU suddenly came up with the idea of an “Irish backstop”.It wanted Britain to promise that, unless it came up with a long-term ­trading ­relationship that satisfied ­Brussels, it would stay in the customs union and leave Northern Ireland under EU regulations.Stupidly, British negotiators accepted the backstop. Wisely, our MPs did not.The backstop would mean Brussels continued to control Britain’s trade deals with non-European countries after we left.It would mean placing part of our country under permanent EU jurisdiction.MPs threw the deal out. Then something sensible happened.Leavers and Remainers began to talk directly to each other and hammered out a deal that both sides could live with.There were lots of aspects of the ­withdrawal agreement that Eurosceptics resented.They didn’t like being non- voting members for another  months.They didn’t like Euro judges continuing to rule here even after we had left.They didn’t like forking out more than billion quid in exchange for the better part of bugger all.But they were ready to make ­compromises. If the Irish ­backstop were removed, they’d swallow the rest of the withdrawal terms.On Tuesday, the House of Commons adopted this position. The EU responded with a theatrical snort of indignation.“We stand by the agreement that we have negotiated,” said Michel Barnier, the European Commission’s negotiator.“The withdrawal agreement is not ­renegotiable,” said Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission.But hang on. Juncker is simultaneously telling us thatwe alter our red lines — by, for example, agreeing to a ­permanent customs union — then the agreement could indeed be reopened.So there is plainly no technical or legal reason why the backstop could not be removed or at least time-limited.Nor, by the way, is anyone still ­pretending that, without the backstop, there will be checkpoints in Londonderry and Crossmaglen.The Irish government has confirmed that,there is no deal, it will not place any infrastructure at the border.The British Government has been saying the same all along.Barnier says there would be ways to carry out necessary checks away from the frontier.In other words, the whole row is about a border that no one is going to build anyway.It’s ­surreal. There is plainly no way the House of Commons is going to accept the backstop.It also became clear on ­Tuesday there is no majority for a ­second ­referendum, because the last thing Jeremy Corbyn wants is to have to come down on one side or the other.That leaves only two options. Either the backstop is dropped but everything  is agreed, or the backstop is lost and so is everything .From the EU’s point of view, it must surely be preferable to agree the bulk of the Withdrawal Agreement, including reciprocal citizens’ rights and the ­£billion payment, while finding an alternative way to guarantee the Irish border stays open.From Dublin’s point of view, the logic is even stronger.Insisting on the backstop risks,not a hard border, certainly more dislocation between the Republic of Ireland and the UK — the very thing the backstop is ­supposed to prevent.The EU has calculated the cost will be worse for Britain than for ­Continental states, since cross-Channel trade is ­proportionately more important for us.But, by that measure, it is more ­important still for Ireland.In private, some Continental politicians are pushing for a pragmatic outcome — one that minimises disruption and ­preserves the long-term alliance between the UK and its neighbours.You especially hear these arguments in countries that trade heavily with Britain, such as Denmark and the Netherlands.You also hear them from governments that want to ensure the rights of their citizens in Britain are guaranteed.But for Eurocrats, in particular the anti-British Martin Selmayr who has seized control of negotiations, this isn’t about finding an outcome that works.If it were, the EU could have signed a continuity deal with Britain easily.The truth is many Euro-fanatics are happy to inflict pain on the EU  ­provided they inflict even more on us.If their view prevails over that of the pragmatists, then Britain has no option but to leave without an agreement. It is never sensible to give into blackmail.If the choice is between No Deal and surrendering part of our country, we will choose No Deal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories must remain united on brexit
story: That’s why, despite the world watching to seeit is capable of reasonable ­compromise, its eurocrats remained so pig-headedly defiant yesterday.Their confected rage and ridiculous pretence at still being confused over what Britain wants are stalling tactics.The hope being that in the new round of votes on February  Tory Remainers, some in Cabinet, blink first. That this time they back a motion preventing us leaving without a deal on March , setting up the potential reversal of Brexit.They must not. The cost to the country and their party will be catastrophic.The Sun does not want No Deal but the threat of it is our greatest leverage. We must not give it up.It is equally dangerousBrexiteers overplay their hand. They have pushed Theresa May in the right direction — but they must now be realistic. A Remainer-stuffed ­Parliament may see to that, however bullish eurosceptic MPs are today.Meanwhile, two things must happen: While No Deal is still possible we must turbo-charge our preparations for it.And Brussels must be left in no doubt . . . not one penny of our exit bill will be paidit happens.IRELAND’S naive PM Leo Varadkar will deserve much of the blame for the misery and chaos No Deal would unleash on his people and across Europe.“We could find ourselves in  or  weeks’ time needing to find a lot of money to save people’s jobs,” he admits.It is time, then, for him to stop posing as a hardman and do the right thing.It is absurd hyperbole to claim Ireland would be betrayed by giving us a legally binding escape option from the backstop at some hypothetical future point.A hard border will happen onlyEU obstinacy pushes us into No Deal.
