title: foreign aid source of corruption
story: Can I start the ball rolling  And maybe then you’d like to hear from a few readers. The people who can’t get beds in our hospitals, or a place for their kids in the local school. All the while that £billion is being spent on fabulously berserk ­projects in the developing world.To her total credit, Mordaunt has said that our current level of spending on overseas aid is unsustainable. It’s been rising every year. Due to a law passed by the coalition government, we have to spend . per cent of our income on aid to the Third World each year.So right now we spend just under £billion. And where does this money go  No less than  per cent of it is siphoned off to global outfits like that most useless of organisations, the United Nations.This is the body which sent out some dimbo Australian envoy to tick off our Government about economic policy. An organisation which elected Saudi Arabia on to its Women’s Rights Commission. An anti-Western and rabidly anti-Israeli convocation of leftie Third World thugs with chips on their shoulders.The world would be enormously improvedthe UN was shut down tomorrow. And the rest of it  Some of the stuff you wouldn’t believe. A total of £, went to a project investigating Tibetan verbs. Nope, not kidding.I would assume that “climb” was one of the verbs they were investigating. They use that a lot, over there. Thanks to our overseas aid, someone, ­somewhere is now able to say in Tibetan: “F*** me, is that a yeti  Run away!”Then there’s the £, spent on a scheme to stop Indian schoolchildren imbibing sugary drinks. India itself gives overseas aid and has an income rather bigger than our own. Where is the point Another six-figure sum was spent ­persuading Chinese people not to smoke too much — China! The second richest country in the world.Another one was to help Indian workers cool their work­stations down — this in a country which has its own space programme, for Chrissakes. So much of our money is swallowed up by useless leftie quangos and charities to keep themselves in jobs.Still more is pocketed by despots in the horrible countries they run. It is a source of corruption and dependency. It makes things worse. And when we tried to ert our overseas aid to some of the Caribbean countries stricken by hurricanes we were told we couldn’t — they were too rich!It’s a nonsense and a racket. If I thought our overseas aid, in its current form, really alleviated misery and suffering I’d be all for it. That’s why I agreed with the last secretary of state, Priti Patel, who wanted to give a decent chunk to the Israel Defence Forces, which saves a lot of lives in Syria.So my recommendation would be to end it all NOW. Divert the money into our beleaguered and creaking infrastructure. And when a tragedy occurs overseas — sure, splash the cash.Anyway, Penny — hope I’ve helped by starting the conversation. Over to you, babes.SCOTTISH politician Ross Greer has already been called a “ginger turd” by Piers Morgan, and I don’t think I can improve on that. But it’s his ignorance and stupidity that staggers – rather than his hatred for Great Britain, which is something we’re used to from north of the border.Greer described Winston Churchill as a white supremacist, a mass murderer and a racist, and likened him to Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin. He says he is simply challenging the “myth” of Churchill. No, Ross, you’re not.You’re just pig ignorant, with a very poor grasp of history. Of course Churchill was racist. Just about everybody was of his age at that time.If you can’t see the importance of Churchill to winning the Second World War – against REAL racists, REAL mass murderers – when Britain stood alone, then you lack all sense of context and proportion.The more I think about it, the more I reckon “ginger turd” was an understatement.HERO of the week is the excellent Rachel Riley, who has been speaking out against anti-Semitism. As a consequence, she now needs greater security when she’s doing TV’s ­Countdown. The left-wing Jew-hating trolls have been after her.Rachel,  said: “The more I speak, the more abuse I get, and the more abuse I get, the more I speak. It’s got to the point where I can’t look at my Twitter feed any more. It’s just a constant stream.”She’s pretty clear who is behind it, too.  A lot of the abuse comes from people who sign off with the hashtag JCPM.SO, Labour MP Fiona Onasanya is off to prison. Found guilty in court of lying through her teeth.But the remarkable thing is she’s still going to be paid as an MP while she’s inside. She has refused to resign her seat and so her £, salary will continue to be paid by the rest of us.If you got sent to the nick, do you think your employers would continue to pay your wages  You’d be out on your ear. It’s kind of ­outrageous, no THIS cultural appropriation business is getting out of hand. Marks  Spencer has been slammed by leftie nutters with nothing better to do with their time. For selling a biryani wrap.They say it’s not authentic. Well of course it’s not bleedin’ authentic.  This is the UK, not Mumbai. Singer Katy Perry was attacked for wearing a kimono because she isn’t Japanese.White people in the US get criticised for wearing training shoes or sporting afros – that’s appropriating black culture, apparently. Though I think it was white folks who invented training shoes. Thing is, cultural appropriation is brilliant.It’s the way we have of sharing our respective cultures.  think it’s wonderful that countries outside Europe and the US have “culturally appropriated” democracy, sanitisation, railways, computers and so on. I wish more would do the same.SOMALIA is the most corrupt country in the world, according to a list compiled by a group called Transparency International.Not a great surprise, is it  Nor to see most of the rest of Africa hogging the bottom quarter of the world table.It’s bad governance and corruption that is keeping Africa poor – not colonialism. You can tell that the compilers of the report are lefties, though. Asked what countries were becoming more corrupt recently, they named the US, Hungary and Brazil. All three have elected right-wing governments.A NEW study says that women who wear short skirts are more likely to be ­promoted.The lesson I’d take from this,I were a women, is to wear a short skirt to work. But I don’t think that’s the lesson they mean us to take.I wonderwomen who wear short skirts but have the legs of an obese ­elephant also are more likely to get ­promoted I think that’s the next study for those researchers at the ­University of Surrey.I TOLD you last week that the reason we haven’t had a proper winter yet is that the people who run winter couldn’t agree on stuff.Such as whether it should be a hard winter, with lots of snow, no winter at all or a compromise deal with a backstop of some sleet for a bit.But I understand that on Tuesday the President of ­Winter won an astonishing ­victory and was able to push her deal through.Which was why it immediately snowed like hell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit tourist fly larvae forehead african holiday
story: She landed in the UK with a growing lump on her head - only to discover that she actually had a load of baby flies buried into her scalp.It wasnt until about nine days after landing on home turf that she realised something was wrong, and headed to AE.Medics first said that her swollen lump was simply a bug bite, and she was sent home with a course of antibiotics.Three days later, however, the lump had grown bigger and more painful. The swelling on her forehead now extended to include more of her face and eyelids, and she experienced sharp, shooting pains in the area.So she ed to hospital, and this time, docs discovered an opening in the centre of the lump which was leaking a watery discharge.According to Dr Farah Shahi, an infectious disease specialist at York Teaching Hospital who treated the woman, the opening was actually a breathing hole for a baby fly or maggot.Doctors applied petroleum jelly to the area which essentially blocked the insects source of air - forcing it to move towards the surface of the skin.After that, they were able to remove the live maggot from the womans forehead before it was sent to the London School of Tropical Medicine for examination.The larva was identied as Lunds fly - a rare species from the rainforests in Africa.An ultrasound found that there were more baby flies in the womans forehead and she had to have surgery to remove them.These flies dont usually infect people, according to the British Medical Journal case report.So, how did it come to buried into her face The most likely explanation is that she wrapped her hair in a damp towel that was infested with maggots, Dr Shahi told Live Science.The towel had been hanging on an outdoor clothing line, and a fly couldve laid its eggs on the towel, which hatched into maggots.Theres only been one other case in the UK of such an infestation its super unusual for these flies to burrow into foreheads as they usually go for the skin on the chest, back, belly and thighs.After four days in hospital, the woman was sent home.

We have commented on reports but we havent seen a change there.This is where I talk about the isolation. We go out there. We make these tough decisions and we often take quite a lot of criticism for the stance we take but we dont always see the enforcement action we would like to see.Mr Tryl added that while Ofsted can highlight segregation in its inspection reports, laws can only be enforced by the Department for Education.He said: Our inspectors are going out and having to make some quite tricky judgements where there are those potential clashes [between laws and religious freedoms].We perhaps don’t always feel we get the support we need from the rest of Government in pushing that forward.Ofsted rated the school as inadequate in .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit latest cabinet remainer block no deal brussels
story: Amber Rudd and Greg Clark warned last night they WILL stop us leaving with nothing on March .It comes after MPs rejected a plan earlier this week from Labours Yvette Cooper to delay Brexitwe were heading for a No Deal.Business Secretary Greg Clark said last night: Ive always been very clear. I think to leave in a disorderly way on the  March would be very bad for everyone in the economy.I will do everything that I can to make sure that doesnt happen.That is the purpose of having a position of influence in government, to be able to do that.Amber Rudd backed up his comments with a supportive tweet last night, adding Well said.Their warnings come as this morning Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt hinted that Brexit could have to be delayeda deal isnt done soon.But Mr Clark actually went even further on ITVs Peston show last night, hinting that he wants the PM to reach out to Labour and offer a customs union with the bloc to win over the Opposition.He said that because of the close result of the referendum, politicians needed to make sure the deal was getting more support than just winning by a vote or two.And he went on: Not only do I think it is necessary for people to come together across partisan lines, but actually I thinkwe are to properly move forward I don’t think we should aim for this deal to pass by a majority of one or two …I would like to see a substantial majority for a deal.Yesterday Mrs May held talks with Jeremy Corbyn where the pair discussed a customs union, which the Labour boss wants.But the discussions soon descended into chaos after he accused her of running down the clock and she denied going soft on the EU.On Tuesday night MPs opted not to back a Remainer plan to put off our EU exit by up to a year to avoid us leaving with nothing.But MPs did vote to back a separate amendment saying Britain shouldnt leave with nothing, indicating it would be incredibly dficult for the PM to push that plan through.Shes refused to take the option off the table because it would take the pressure off Brussels to give us a good deal that we want.The PM saw off a possible rebellion on the Cooper plan this week when she promised ministers that they could have another say on stopping No Deal later on.Other Cabinet ministers have urged her to plan and get ready for us to leave with nothing - with is looking more and more likely as the clock ticks down to exit day in March.Meanwhile, earlier today the Institute for Government said today that the UK is unprepared for leaving without an agreement.IFG director Bronwen Maddox told the BBC: The UK is not ready for no-deal.

title: brexit news delayed theresa may deal jeremy hunt
story: The Foreign Secretary admitted Britain may NOT leave the EU on March  - evenwe do manage to agree a deal.Its the first time one of the PMs inner circle has ever said that the Brexit date could be pushed back.Mr Hunt told the BBCs Today programme thatBritain and the EU strike a Brexit deal in the near future.Butit takes more than a month then the scheduled Leave date could be postponed to give Parliament more time to pass crucial legislation needed to give it legal effect.Askedthere would be a delay, Mr Hunt said: I think that depends on how long this process takes.It is true thatwe ended up approving a deal in the days before March , then we might need some extra time to pass critical legislation.Butwere able to make progress sooner then that might not be necessary.He added: Were not in a position to know which of those scenarios will happen.Legal experts said this week that there is still time for Parliament to pass all the laws needed to put a Brexit deal into effect.But they warned that the time is running outa deal isnt signed off in the near future.Despite the backlog, MPs arent scheduled to hold any debate or votes on Brexit next week.If there were a last-minute delay, it would be likely to last no more than a month or two.But top Brexiteer Steve Baker blasted: Any delay before a deal is secured would be a crass negotiating error.Labour Remainer Rachel Reeves said: Jeremy Hunt’s words just add to the impression that the Government do not know what they are doing and are staggering from crisis to crisis.Mrs May yesterday refused to rule out a delay after being challenged directly at Prime Ministers Questions.But efforts by Remainer MPs to impose a delay of up to nine months were defeated on Tuesday night.Mr Hunt is today attending a meeting of EU foreign ministers in Romania where he will lobby them to accept Mrs Mays demands to fix the Irish backstop in order to agree a Brexit deal.

title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens - who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home - feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsNo Deal Brexit: Armed Forces set to hold war games within daysSome , troops are being held at readiness to provide logistical supportthe UK crashes out in a chaotic no deal BrexitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN News, troops are being held at readiness for a no-deal scenario "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Armed Forces are set to hold war games for a No Deal Brexit within days, it has emerged.The reports come after it was confirmed , troops are being held at readiness for a no-deal scenario on March , with the Armed Forces ready to call up reserves.According to Sky News, a number of no-deal war games will be held by the armed forces in the coming days.A source claimed the story referred to a desk-based exercise rather than one involving troops in the field. There would then be an exercise across government towards the end of February. A Whitehall source told the Mirror the exercises were designed to see where we are and what we can do, but added: It’s not boots on the ground. Troops are understood to be on standby for logistical supportroads and ports are gridlocked and food supplies run low after March .   The focus is understood to be more on logistics than the threat of civil unrest, although plans are in place to impose martial lawneeded. Sky News obtained a note from Stephen Lovegrove, the permanent secretary at the Ministry of Defence, to staff before Christmas.It said of Brexit preparations: “We will not only have to continue this hard work but treat it as our highest priority.A spokesman for the MoD told Sky: We routinely undertake planning across defence to ensure we are prepared for a range of scenarios and Brexit contingency planning is no dferent. We are working across government to ensure our people, the defence estate, and our national and international commitments would be unaffected by a no-deal Brexit. There would be no impact on previously agreed activity, including overseas operations, exercises and UK contingency operations.

title: theresa mays brexit victory not
story: NewsopinionTheresa Mays Brexit victory is not quite what you thinkSanity is beginning to reassert itself, in the place where dreams meet geographyShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Hooray and huzzah, hang out the bunting and issue high-fives all round. Something has finally happened on Brexit.What has happened is that the Tories have agreed to stop screaming up their own bumholes and scream at the EU instead. This will come as a relief to all those who witnessed their -month act of circular self-abuse, but they did at least give us a new definition for windbags.  This has been described as Theresa Mays best day at work since  by all those people who have not had enough fresh air recently. Her great success is that someone  has been able to unite the Tories around a version of Brexit that is impossible, impractical and undeliverable.They even managed to persuade  of the crazier members of the Labour Party to join them in this unmedicated dreamland, where the DUP have long gambolled in the insane belief it will reignite their holy war against the Fenians.The Tories have, for the first time in two and a half years, decided what they want. The problem is that it is the opposite of what Theresa has done or can do. On November , , she told the House of Commons: The Brexit talks are about acting in the national interest, and that means making what I believe to be the right choices, not the easy ones.I know there are some who have said I should simply rip up the UK’s commitment to a backstop, but this would have been an entirelyirresponsible course of action. It would have meant reneging on a promise made to the people of Northern Ireland during the referendum campaign and afterwards - that under no circumstances would Brexit lead to ato the borders of the past - and it would have made it impossible to deliver a withdrawal agreement.As Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, I have a responsibility to people in every part of our country, and I intend to honour that promise.And last night, she was told to do all the things she didnt want to do on the grounds that doing them would be f***ing disastrous. What has happened is this: . Theresa presented Plan A, which guaranteed the rights and safety of .m British citizens in Northern Ireland, and was punched in the face by Parliament which snarled stuff em.. Theresa presented Plan B, which was much the same but had a dferent letter on the front page, and Parliament said well maybe so long as we can decide to say stuff em later, slapped Theresa lightly and sent her back to Brussels. The EU are about to say alors, but you people cest tres thick. Theresas people are already briefing therell be a Plan C. And I can tell you now whats in it.  Plan C will have moved on signicantly from Plan B by being more like Plan A. Itll have the same words in much the same order, with very similar promises about protecting those .m British citizens with a backstop, and it will get voted through by Parliament for two reasons.First, theyve voted on it twice already, and have been dragged towards accepting a version of it. On the third time of asking, theyll be ready to back ANY version, in much the same way a man who has kicked himself in the head will wonderits possible to do it again.Imagine such a person, and you will have invented Iain Duncan Smith.  Secondly, there will be no other option.There is now no Parliamentary time left for Theresas deal to get the necessary legislation through before its self-imposed Article  deadline. There isnt even enough time for the new laws we need to trade under WTO rules in the event of a No Deal Brexit.By automatic operation of the law, on March  all EU treaties cease to be effective. Predicted results include motorways turning into lorry parks, medicines being rationed, the imposition of martial law and Jacob Rees-Mogg declaring an ancestral right to eat peasants. Even those Parliamentarians whove been hoarding gold and have a Barbudan bolthole dont want that sort of legacy hung around their neck, so extending the deadline is inevitable. And fortunately, the law they wrote about all this allows for a minister to change the exit date whenever they fancy. And most importantly there is no other option for the border in Northern Ireland. No way to take back control, no way to superimpose a UK referendum on to a people who had a referendum on this already, and managed a % mandate on an % turnout. People traffickers and drug smugglers dont fill in customs forms, weve no way to police a -mile border with  crossing points, and as the cherry on the cake elderly IRA bombers are coming out of retirement to make car bombs for new splinter groups.The only way all these things were resolved was with an open border, that allowed the unionists to remain British while allowing the republicans to pretend they were Irish.No-one has an alternative to that, and it is a fact of quite beautul irony that the only way anyones going to Brexit isthey refuse to take back control of our sole land border with the EU.So we wont Brexit on March , because we cant. Well call it Brexit a bit later, and it wont be because all this arguing was just to get us to the point where we could discuss what Brexit will look like. And it wont ever BE Brexit, because every power-crazed demand the backbench fruitloops have made has had to be dropped - when courts ruled it unlawful, when public opinion swung against them, and when Theresa persisted them into submission.Her problem is that all the Brexit chaos has been laid at her door. She has been blamed for the indecision, poor negotiation and infighting, for a dud election and international humiliation.Yet somehow, through either great stupidity or brilliant stratagem, she has forced her party and the country to agree what it never would have done in , a year or even  months ago. Leavers and Remainers now fervently believe any deal is better than none at all, appreciate Northern Irelands problems in a way few ever bothered to do, andthe polls are right are coming to the opinion that the current deal we have with the EU is the best of all possible worlds.What happened last night is that the hardliners have taken their latest of , tiny steps towards admitting their dream is just that. Thats why Theresa is stronger than ever, why the Labour Party is on the back foot and the EU is scratching its head.Sanity is beginning to reassert itself. It says do something, avert disaster, extract cranium from bum, ask yourselfthis is a good idea. All those Parliamentarians who complained Parliament was being undemocratic are now praising it for embodying the will of the people.Theres months and probably years more of arseing about, of course, and any group of people with a fetish for rectal screaming are probably going to try it a few times more before they realise it hurts too much.Sanity is not immediate. But it is there, flickering gently in the place where dreams meet geography.

story: NewsGlamorous grandma, , gets confused for her -year-old daughters sisterBecky Brown, , from Basildon in Essex, says strangers are stunned to find out her daughter Scarlett, , a former Miss Teen Queen UK, isnt her siblingShareCommentsByHannah Smith:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsScarlett, , with mum Becky, , at Scarletts baby shower "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grandmother claims she often gets confused for her beauty queen daughters SISTER because she looks to young.Becky Brown, , and Scarlett Saunders, , say they look so alike that strangers are often stunned to find out theyre not siblings. The mum, who puts her youthful looks down to good genes, and her daughter have a close relationship and similar fashion sense, regularly sharing clothes as theyre both a size . The soon-to-be gran-of-two, who has no special dietary, fitness or beauty regime, says her young appearance is all thanks to the luck of the genetic draw.  Becky, of Basildon, Essex, said: People do say that Scarlett and I look alike. Its very flattering. People are shocked that were mum and daughter when we go out together. They say we look like sisters. Me and Scarlett are very alike in a lot of ways. Not just looks but also our personalities. Were very close. She loves to raid my wardrobe. Even when she was little she would be in there putting on all my makeup and trying on clothes and shoes. When she got older she would just help herself.   We can still share now because were a similar size. Its nice we can share and both have similar tastes. I dont have any secret trick. I should do more really to stay in shape. I think its all genetic from my mother. Shes  on her next birthday and she has always been very glamorous. Becky also turns heads when shes out with her granddaughter Arabella Ray,  months, as people are shocked to hear the tot refer to her as nan. Some surprised strangers even take the time to come over to tell Becky she doesnt look old enough to have a grandchild, which she says is very sweet.   Becky said: When I go out with Arabella people are shocked Im her nan. Its so nice for me. Its really sweet. People presume Im her mum and when they hear her call me nan they come over to tell me I dont look old enough. Scarlett, who is currently seven months pregnant with her second miracle baby, was diagnosed with leukemia aged nine and doctors warned her she may never conceive. Five years after winning her battle with cancer, Scarlett was crowned Miss Teen Queen UK in .  Scarlett says her days are slightly less glamorous now but she still loves getting made up for a day of lunch and shopping with her mum. Scarlett hopes shell look as good as Becky when shes older. She said: People do say that my mum could be my sister, especially on Instagram when they see a photo of us together. A lot of the time people think my little girl is hers too. People are shocked when they hear Arabella calling her nan. She does look good for her age. I hope I look like her at her age.

story: NewsMums shocking decline after becoming cocaine dealer when marriage fell apartAngela Davey, , is on the run from police after failing to appear in court after being caught selling drugsShareByTommy Lumby:,  JAN NewsAngela Davey, pictured when she graduated from the University of East Anglia in  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA history teacher whose le fell apart after she became a cocaine dealer teacher is on the run from police. Angela Davey, , was a married mum-of-two with a successful career before she got involved with a gang selling heroin and crack cocaine. It happened after her marriage hit trouble - and now her family have begged her to give herself up. Davey had been due to be sentenced for dealing cocaine after being caught during an undercover drugs operation. A close family member, who asked not to be named, said: Angela went from being a bright, well-educated person to somebody who the last time she was seen, was sleeping in a shop doorway in Norwich. Shes hopelessly addicted to drugs.  The relative said he feared the family would not get her back, adding: Her brain has changed. Everybody wants her to just come in so we can help her to deal with the situation. Davey had been due to appear at Norwich Crown Court along with David Teixeira, , from London, who was described as being the branch manager of the county lines gang, transporting drugs from the capital to London. Jack Parrish, , from Norwich, was said to be the main local dealer on the streets, while Tara Kelf, , allowed her Norwich flat to be used as a base for the operation.   All three defendants admitted conspiracy to supply Class A drugs and were jailed for a total of  years. A -year-old childhood friend, who wishes to remain anonymous, told local media that Angela was an incredibly intelligent woman. Angela, from Norwich, Norfolk, is reported to have studied history at university and trained as a teacher before working at Hewett Academy in Norwich, and then moved to work at a special needs school. She is believed to have bought a house with her husband, with whom she had two children. However, friends said her le took a sharp turn for the worse after her marriage broke down. She is said to have met a man on the dating app Tinder, and soon became embroiled in the world of drugs. Her friend said: “If she continues in this lestyle she will die.” She added that prison could be the only way to save her from potential death.  The former teacher reportedly ended up living in a camper van, before resorting to sleeping in a tent near a footpath. The new occupant of a semi-detached property in Norwich, where Angela is believed to have lived  months ago, said that rubbish and drug needles were left at the home. The -year-old woman, who wished to remain anonymous, also said that childrens things and artwork were also left there.  Speaking to local press, she said: To think a le could go downhill so quickly.” Davey has links in Thrapston, in Northamptonshire and may also have travelled to London. Anyone who may have seen Angela Davey, or knows of her whereabouts, should contact Norfolk Police on .

title: psycho man causes girlfriend to
story: NewsPsycho causes girlfriend to lose child and home in terrying three-week relationshipIan Brewster pinned down girlfriend Kayleigh Rutter and held a kne to her throat and went berserk when she received a Facebook message from a male friendShareByJonathan Pickles:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsIan Brewster, , attacked his girlfriend at knepointLtd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA psycho boyfriend was so controlling during a three-week relationship his girlfriend lost custody of her child and her home, a court heard. Ian Brewster, , attacked his partner Kayleigh Rutter at knepoint, stopped her from seeing friends and threatened to smash up her propertymen contacted her on Facebook during their brief romance. In one attack, Miss Rutter, , was pinned to the bed and had a blade held to her throat, leaving her fearing she would die. During another attack, Brewster, from Hyde, Greater Manchester, went berserk when his friend sent a Facebook message to Miss Rutter. He told her: Get him around here and I will stab you first and make him watch, then I will stab him through the neck.   The mother-of-one blamed Brewsters controlling behaviour for her subsequently losing a custody battle over her daughter from a previous relationship. She later moved into a womens refuge to get away from him and he has now been jailed. In a statement Miss Rutter said: His actions have made me feel scared and frightened. I also feel very angry as he has messed things up for me - I have lost a custody battle for my daughter, which is why I didnt want the police involved. I am always on edge now and in constant fear. At the moment, I just feel numb - I dont know how to feel.  At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, heavily tattooed Brewster blamed his paranoid behaviour on him being ly branded a sex offender at the age of . He was jailed for  months after he was found guilty of controlling or coercive behaviour upon Miss Rutter plus other charges of assault upon another ex-girlfriend and criminal damage to her TV. The court heard Miss Rutters ordeal began just days after the pair began a relationship in Apr-l last year. Joshua Bowker, prosecuting, said: He asked her to go to the shops and get groceries but when she did, he accessed her Facebook account and sent messages to all her male friends saying that they couldnt contact her anymore.  To justy this to her, he said that he had been cheated on in the past anda male ever sent her a message, he would threaten to smash her phone in her face. On one occasion, he punched the bedroom door three times, creating holes in it. Another time, one of the defendants friends called her and he put his foot through the door. Miss Rutter said he was going psycho and he pinned her to the bed and had a kne against her throat. She said that she thought she was going to die. She was so scared in her own home, he would put the knives out of reach from her so that only he could get them.  On May , she received a phone call from a friend using her boyfriends mobile and the defendant became angry again. He said to her get him around here and I will stab you first and make him watch, then I will stab him through the neck. The next day, her mother picked her up from her home in the morning and took her away. He sent her more abusive messages on Facebook when police were notied the police, he accused Miss Rutter of being a liar.  Brewster denied wrongdoing but failed to attend his trial in August last year and was convicted in his absence. He was later put on a police wanted list and was arrested last Christmas. His lawyer, Ben Knight, said in mitigation: The defendant is paranoid about why people want to be in relationships with him and he is paranoid about infidelity, and I think this controlling behaviour bolsters his own self-esteem. Also, at  years of age, he was accused of sexual assault. No further action was taken at that time but the accusation has been used by a number of people in his le as a weapon against him. On social media, people have shared photos of him saying that he is a paedophile. As a result of this vigilante behaviour on social media, he has spent quite a lot of time looking over his shoulders. He did not commit any such offence, but that does not matter in the court of public opinion and Facebook. He has been ly painted as a paedophile and has been assaulted because of that. Sentencing, the judge Miss Recorder Samantha Presland told Brewster: Over a period of three weeks, you engaged in pretty relentless, violent, coercive and controlling behaviour. You would regularly threaten Miss Rutter with a kne, not let her see her friends, and you threatened to stab her and her friends. She eventually had to go and live with her mother. You are displaying destructive co-dependant behaviour which is not good for you or for them and it needs to to stop.

title: schoolboy 13 kicked neck vicious
story: NewsSchoolboy, , kicked in neck by vicious bullies says I might as well kill myselfDanial Elliott, from Beverley, East Yorkshire, initially hid his injuries from his worried mum Vikki who says her son threatened to hang himself before ChristmasShareCommentsByAlex GroveBradley Jolly:,  JAN NewsDanial Elliott, , was taken to hospital after the attack"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A -year-old boy said he might as well kill himself after vicious bullies ambushed and attacked him in a sickening street attack. Danial Elliott was beaten up as he walked home from school last Thursday. The youngster was hit from behind and kicked in the back and neck by his attackers who then fled the scene, Hull Live says.The schoolboy initially hid his injuries from his worried mum Vikki Elliott until they got back home. But the stress of his attack alongside being repeatedly bulled at school led to him later threaten serious self-harm. Ms Elliott, from Beverley, East Yorkshire, said: He looked fine when he got into the car. He said nothing to me which is not unusual and because of the bullying he will dust himself off as he is the eldest sibling.   We got into the house and he was stomping about I was asking what was wrong. He got into a bit of a confrontation with me before going into the hallway, putting his hands on his head and dragging his nails into his own face. He then shouted I might as well kill myself. The mum-to-four, , said Danial has been bullied since primary school, with children targeting him because of his bowel problems. She added: They call him things like smelly, a toilet, they call him all sorts. He doesn’t tell me anything now because he just gets fed up with repeating it.   It’s getting to the point where they are bullying him that badly that he doesn’t want to be around here anymore and before Christmas he threatened to hang himself. We are keeping an eye on him but there is nothing we can do to help him with this condition he has got. He is on medication andit stops working we have to up the dosage. He sees doctors and paediatricians but there is nothing  we can do until he is older. After the attack, Danial ended up in hospital until am on Friday, January , and he had to have his head put in a neck brace for extra protection. They could have killed him, Ms Elliott said. One kick in the wrong place could have broken his neck or paralysed him and the people who did this need to understand that.  You hear about it all the time – one punch in the wrong place and you can kill someone. They could have left me without my son and his three younger siblings without a brother and that is just devastating to think about. They were so worried on Thursday when he was in hospital and losing Danial would have left a big whole in our family.The incident has been reported to Humberside Police but it cannot be confirmed whether Danial was attacked by the same bullies who have been making his le hell at school.His mum continued: He is not ready to go back to school. He is so withdrawn and becomes even more withdrawn when school is mentioned. He is in a lot of pain and I want to doctors to write a note so that the school knows he needs time to recuperate. title: secret tricks prince george princess
story: NewsSecrets of George and Charlottes nursery - and how nanny makes them behaveNorland Nanny Maria Borrallo was hired by Kate Middleton and Prince William and now looks after Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince LouisShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsShes never too far from the children "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Maria Borrallo has one of the most prestigious child care jobs in the country right now - helping to bring up the future king. She was hired by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge when Prince George was just a few months old and now also looks after Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis .She trained at the famous Norland College, the countrys top training centre for childcare, and has a lot of experience. Author Louise Heren spent a year at the college researching a documentary, so knows exactly what the students are taught. Speaking to , shes revealed some of the techniques and tricks the nannies use to ensure kids behave - and its likely Maria is using them on the royal children.   She believes that despite the extraordinary lives they have ahead of them, le at home will be fairly normal.Louise, author of Nanny in a Book , said: Given what we have seen of Catherine when she is out in public, shes very hands on.I imagine her relationship with Maria is very close and they collaborate greatly on the care of the children. Ive spoken to nannies who have worked with other royal families and le is pretty normal. You get up, have breakfast, you go to school and you wear your school unorm whether you like it or not. It would be quite like the average British school children. Here are some of the Norland Nannies tips and tricks: Always involve children in planning Once the child is old enough, Norland Nannies believe its important to let them help plan the day. Give them options to pick fromsuch as going to the park, baking a cake or reading. Louise says: It means that the nanny has got some control but the child has chosen what to do and is happy that they got the choice.   Explain exactly what is going to happen when heading out Marias job is unique in that the children she is raising are far from normal and she has to prepare them for royal events and tours. Louise said: Her job is to keep them happy, safe and well but equally they need to be presentable and well behaved when they are on parade. Before royal events she believes Maria and Kate will speak to the children to tell them exactly what is going to happen, who they are going to see and what people are going to do - for example everyone will be waving and they should wave back. Meal times Norland Nannies believe routine is essential for children, especially for big parts of the day. Louise said: Children understand routine but they like to be informed of that routine. Evenlunchtime is half an hour later, the clues that lead up to it stay the same. Ten minutes to go, wash your hands, can you help me lay the table    The nannies also use meal times as a key learning opportunity. Setting the table involves the child counting out the right amount of cutlery for each person and the right number of plates and cups. They can also practice their colours when picking out dferent items. The nannies also try to give children choices when it comes to their dinner. For example, which two vegetables would you like today  This allows them a choice and also means you have a responsethey are unhappy about eating it. Louise said: If they are informed beforehand you dont get a grizzly child. Bedtime Much like meal times, routine is key. Bath, pajamas and a bedtime story every night help the child know its time for bed.  Louise, who has also written a book on the history of Norland College , said: It is training resilience in the children that they are happy to be on their own in the dark at night.Her relationship with the children Louise said: [Maria] will be friendly with the children butthey need a little bit of discipline shes more than able to step in and do that. Their approach is very nurturing and loving. It is entirely centred around the children.  It is about training the children by example rather than just telling them. Its about saying why did you do that  Think about how that would have been received. Make everything an opportunity to learn The day is filled with dferent learning opportunities. Nannies will ask the children to count dferent things. Louise believes that Maria will probably ask the children how to say dferent things in Spanish and French, as they are learning both languages.   Tantrums There isnt a set way Norland Nannies deal with tantrums, as every child is dferent. But they will always try to spot the tantrum before it unfolds. Louise says that there is normally an early trigger, so the trick the nannies are taught is to spot this earlier. Speaking about the dreaded terrible twos, she said: The child has the mental ability to want something but they havent got the language ability to say can you get that for me. The tantrum can build because youre not observing what theyre trying to get or do. Frustration is building. One word that is banned There is one banned word in the Norland College, which probably means Maria doesnt use it when referring to George, Charlotte and Louis. According to Louis, children are always referred to children and NEVER kids.

title: brexit dundee chiefs prepare for martial law empty shelves no fuel and food rationing if there is no deal
story: Dundee chiefs are preparing for the prospect of martial law, empty supermarket shelves, no fuel and food rationing in a “worst case scenario” no-deal Brexit.Such is the concern at the impact on the city and residents that possible emergency measures are already being put in place.Dundee City Council, along with other organisations including Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, revealed the work being done to protect provisions in the city should Britain tumble out of the EU without a trade deal.Councillor Will Dawson is heading the local authority group that is preparing for the worst possible scenarios.He said this could include food and fuel being stockpiled and rationing implemented. vw, px"   vw, px"  Mr Dawson said: “We have no definite or accurate prediction of what could happen but what we are doing is preparing for everything and anything.“We have to be prepared for the ‘what  ’ scenario. Rationing and martial law, along with stock piling of food and fuel are among the options we will need to consider. Whatthe fuel runs out  Whatthe medicine runs out  Whatfood can’t get through the ports  WhatEU residents just go home “During a meeting at Cosla last week, it was clear from the discussions that a lot of time and effort is going into these preparations which go from the sublime to the ridiculous. However, we need to ensure that no matter what happens, our city and our country can keep running.“Most of these preparations are being done nationally so there is no fuel or food stockpile in Dundee as such. However, we do know how much fuel that we have and what scenarios could lead to rationing and blue light only situations.”The council’s Labour group leader Kevin Keenan said: “There are resilience teams working on Dundee’s worst case scenario. It is fair to say that in the work they are undertaking, they are considering there could be shortages of foods and fuel. I would not like to set panic out there, but it’s right for this work to be carried out.“We hear from the haulage industry that delays at ports are a high possibility resulting in a delay for foods being delivered to shops. I hope supermarkets are planning for that level of delay.“Other businesses in the city that run a ‘just in time’ manufacture should seriously look at the products that may affect them and build some level of resilience into their purchasing regime until things settle down.”Alison Henderson , CEO of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said: “Brexit’s implications for business and the wider community will bring change for businesses of every size and sector.“We believe all firms – not just those directly and immediately affected – should be undertaking a Brexit ‘health check’, and a broader test of existing business plans.” vw, px"  Cabinet secretary Sir Mark Sedwill denied soldiers would be put on the streets in event of a no deal Brexit. He noted the civil contingencies department – which has the powers to declare a “national emergency” – has been involved in no deal planning.If an “emergency” is declared, the armed forces can be deployeddeemed necessary.

title: dundee uniteds nicky clark says we are making life very hard for ourselves
story: Nicky Clark admits Dundee United are “making it very hard for ourselves” as their bid for promotion to the Premiership stumbles yet again.The Tangerines fell six points behind leaders Ross County and three behind Ayr United after losing to the Honest Men - last Friday.With  matches remaining in the Championship race, Clark admits the Tangerines need to pick up three points more often than not between now and the end of the campaign.And that starts this weekend at home to Greenock Morton.The striker said: “We’re still up there, still round about it but we know we need to pick up now.“The next game is massive for us now, we need three points because we are making it really hard for ourselves but we need to just concentrate on our own matches and it’s important we pick up three points from most games between now and the end of the season.“There is still plenty of time, especially in this league because everybody seems to beat everybody, but it’s games like Friday you need to go and winyou want to win titles.“Friday we didn’t manage that so we only have ourselves to blame.“However, we have Morton this weekend and we can galvanise ourselves and get three points.“Saturday will be tough – it’s all good teams in this league so we need to prepare ourselves this week. The gaffer will get us ready for it and we need to make sure we go and do the business.”The performance at Somerset Park was a bitter disappointment for the  United fans who made the long trip on a Friday night.And Clark admits it wasn’t good enough from the Tangerines.He added: “We went down to Ayr with full intentions of winning the game.“We gave ourselves a chance a couple of weeks ago against Dunfermline when we won and got ourselves up the league but we let ourselves and the fans down on Friday.“The weather meant it was never going to be a pretty game and they got a chance early on and took it.“I think we only had one real chance with Aidan towards the end where the goalie was out quick and made a good save.“All in all it was a very frustrating night and we were very disappointed.”Strong winds made le dficult for all the players but it was clear Ian McCall’s men coped far better with the conditions than United.The home side dominated the opening period and got their goal through Craig Moore early on but the expected response from the Tangerines with the wind in their favour in the second half never really materialised.Clark added: “It was dficult conditions but we’ve all played in wind like that before, we all know what it’s like.“We had a game plan – I don’t knowwe didn’t stick to it but it never happened for us.“We’re disappointed because that’s nine points we’ve given Ayr this season and we’re making it very hard for ourselves.”It’s been a stop-start first season at the club for Clark with a series of injuries curtailing his first-team opportunities.Now, though, he says he’s back to % and ready to help United get back on track.“It’s been very frustrating for me, I’ve missed a lot of games with daft wee injuries here and there where you can’t actually treat them, you just have to leave them until they get better.“It’s been frustrating but I’m back and feeling good now so, hopefully, I can kick on now and help the team get where we want to be.”

title: tom duthie dundee united need to start performing in the big games
story: Despite the major disappointment of the defeat at Ayr United, the consolation for Dundee United fans at the moment has to be the fact they have become genuine promotion contenders under Robbie Neilson.The gap to the top of the table has stretched to six points again because of that Friday night loss at Somerset Park coupled with Ross County’s victory over Alloa on Saturday afternoon.It can’t be forgotten United’s poor goal dference effectively means right now the gap to the top is seven points.With just  games to go, time is also running out for United to make up the lost ground and clinch promotion at the first time of asking.Boosted by the January signings that are set to continue in the final few days of the window,they can gel quickly enough, Neilson will believe the deficit can by clawed back and, in a Championship race that’s seen every team drop points regularly, even a decent winning run could do that.The manager’s overall record since he arrived in October does also give some reason for Arabs not to give up hope just yet.Since his debut win at Partick Thistle in mid-October, with , his team are the leading points gatherers in the second tier.By beating Alloa in Dingwall on Saturday, County took their points tally over the same period to  and while no one would argue the fact promoted Ayr are having an excellent first campaign back at this level, they have been showing signs of running out of steam.Between their hugely impressive - win at Tannadice right at the end of November and their repeat success over United the other night, Ian McCall’s team had gone five league games without a win and also, of course, suffered that humiliating Scottish Cup exit at the hands of juniors Auchinleck Talbot.If that, and the points tally under the new manager, provides encouragement, what continues to be a major concern for United is their poor record against the others at the top end of the table.Friday was their fth clash with the top two on league business and, to date, the record reads played five, lost four, won one, score two and conceded .Add to that a League Cup loss up at County in July and what you have is a worrying statistic.Without wishing to paint an even darker picture, they have also only drawn two clashes with Inverness with both coming when the Highlanders were sitting in one of the promotion play-off places.If they are to realise American owner Mark Ogren’s dream of going up automatically during his first months in charge, it’s a statement of the obvious to say the big-game record has to improve drastically.Should it, United can still get to where they want to be. They’ve two games to come against County and one final crack at Ayr and, of those showdowns, two are at Tannadice.Yes, the two heaviest defeats of the season came there against County and Ayr but under Neilson that second defeat was the only one he’s suffered in seven home games so far.And last time he sent out a team to face County he did mastermind what was without doubt the best win of the campaign to date, a gritty - success on their patch, in November.If the manager can mould his rebuilt team over the next few weeks, wins like that one can be repeated.They’ll have to be, or United’s big-game failures will see them negotiating even more vital outings in the play-offs.
