There will be a workshop in February with members of the third sector, including SNAP, to agree methods of funding and how we can redesign our processes.She added: ldquoOur discussions have been useful and I have given a clear commitment from the council that we will work with the third sector to help lever funding from where as we work together for the benefit of all Highland communities.Ms Walker said: ldquoWhile the meeting was more positive, we are still in a position of not knowing what is going to happen.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Inverness Airport hotel plan takes off
story: The Courtyard by Marriot will be situated within Inverness Airport Business Park and it set to open its doors later this year.Owned and developed by Molo Hotels, the property will be operated by the independent hotel management company RBH.Chief business development officer at RBH, Andrew Robb, said the company is delighted to be working alongside Molo hotels and Polcom Construction for the project.ldquoWersquove forged a strong working relationship with Molo Hotels and Polocom Construction over the years and are thrilled to be working with them on what promises to be another outstanding property, said Mr Robb.The -bedroom hotel plans include meeting and fitness facilities as well as a bar and bistro.Contractor Polocom Construction has started the production of bedrooms in Poland before they are transported to the site near Inverness airport in May.A spokesman for RBH has said that the hotel is set to be open by the end of the year: ldquoWhile we canrsquot give an exact opening date at the moment, the hotel is scheduled to open in quarter  of  she said.Molo Hotels changed their name from Polocom Developments in .Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: New Lochardil hotel owner pledges to make investment
story: NEW owners of a well established Inverness hotel have promised more investment to make it even more attractive to visitors.Lochardil House Hotel has become the second mainland hotel bought by Skye-based Perle Hotels and the group has been advertising for staff to get ready for the summer.The Victorian mansion, which was built in  as the home of Inverness MP Charles Fraser-Mackintosh, has been a hotel since .It was previously owned by Eileen Fraser, who bought the hotel in . More recently she has expanded the hotel with the addition of a purpose-built banqueting suite, a conservatory restaurant, new kitchens and a separate  bedroom garden wing, more than doubling its accommodation provision.Perle Hotels marketing manager Nina Ghita said the group wanted to build on the hotelrsquos heritage and had no plans to change its name.ldquoWe want to keep those unique quirks and the history. Those are really important, but there are always things that can be improved, she said.ldquoWe focus on the Highlands and Islands and we invest quite heavily into the hotels, provide more jobs and just try and make something special within the area. The same thing will be happening with Lochardil. Obviously the hotel is in a really good position as it is. We donrsquot have any concrete plans as yet, but there will be heavy investment down the road.Unlike the grouprsquos previous hotels, which required major renovations, she does not anticipate anything so drastic. There are no immediate plans to add other north hotels to the group, but Ms Ghita pointed out there were opportunities available all the time.ldquoWe are a growing company, she said. ldquoThere will be future expansion plans but nothing concrete at the moment.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds to play Inverness concert
story: They will perform at Bught Park on Saturday, June , as part of lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo, a series of summer music concerts planned for the city.Last year was a successful period for the former Oasis star, who landed a Mercury Prize nomination for the High Flying Birdsrsquo album Who Built The Moon , the bandrsquos third number one in a row. They also toured extensively across North America, Europe and Asia with Noel picking up the Best Album and Solo Artist accolades at the Q Awards.Joining the line-up for the evening, are two big names from the music scene. Indie rock band, Razorlight and Neon Waltz shy- from John OrsquoGroats - will be special guests on June .Local concert promoter, LCC Live is organising this concert, as part of its lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo. Carlie Davidson of LCC Live, said: ldquoNoel is a legend of the music industry, who along with his band, will take to the stage and deliver an array of classic songs from his career including recent hits Holy Mountain and Itrsquos A Beautul World.ldquoWersquore absolutely delighted to be organising his only Scottish outdoor show in  at our fantastic arena in Bught Park. It will be a great night and Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds, is a superb addition to our eclectic series of live concerts this summer.Tickets for Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds concert in Inverness go on sale at am on Friday from Ticketline www.ticketline    or in person from Cafferys Menswear, Eastgate Shopping Centre, Inverness, IV PP.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: One man campaign to safeguard cyclists
story: Allie Middletonfrom Balnakyle Road is concerned about the visibility of a cycle path which cuts through trees and merges with the east junction with Lochy Road and he is urging locals to campaign for improved awareness and traffic calming measures.ldquoI just happen to live opposite the cycle track. I would never be able to forgive myselfsomething happened and I hadnrsquot done something about it, said Mr Middleton.He is particularly concerned that many drivers do not know the cycle track is there because it is set back roughly  metres from the road, through the garden of the Green Drive Hall.Mr Middleton said when the cycle path was upgraded three years ago, a barrier was removed which had separated the path clearly from the road.There is now a sign at the end of the path before it meets the road, warning cyclists to dismount. But Mr Middleton said that the sign was being ignored and there was a danger at the bend where cyclists meet traffic.Speed reducing tables have been installed at the site, but Mr Middleton said: ldquoCars are going over the raised tables at mph and then drivers are putting the foot down in between them.He has reported his concerns to the council who carried out a survey in May last year. It revealed the average speed in the mph zone at the busiest time in the morning is .mph.He is now urging the council to instal signs to alert the drivers to the oncoming cyclists or a speed indicating devicewhich will show road users their speed.The path is used by pupils from Lochardil Primary, Inverness Royal Academy Holm Primary and the Gaelic school.Mr Middleton fears young people on the path may not be seen by fast moving vehicles: ldquoWe have crossed this road many times andin the company of two or four of my grandchildren this is more dficult, the main reason for this is in estimating the speed of accelerating vehicles since the tables were installed said Mr Middleton.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoA mph zone was recently installed in the Culduthel Lochardil area at the request of the community council. The scheme which encompasses Balnakyle Road includes appropriate signage and associated traffic calming features. Highland Council are monitoring speeds and will be making the police awarea persistent speeding problem is demonstrated. The concerns... will be investigated.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: hopes are high for aberdeen women with new management duo
story: Aberdeen Women’s new management team are in no doubt as to their aim for the upcoming campaign – promotion.The Aberdeen FC Ladies senior side was taken over by the men’s club earlier this year, following their relegation to Scottish Women’s Football League Division One .It was their second consecutive drop after they fell out of the top flight two seasons ago.Emma Hunter and Harley Hamdani were unveiled as co-bosses yesterday as Pittodrie chiefs continued to throw their weight behind the team and are targeting ato Scottish Women’s Premier League Two and more.The new season starts for the Reds at home to Inverness Caley Thistle on February .Hunter, who represented Scotland as a player and is assistant coach for the national Under- side, said: “As soon as this was advertised I pounced on it.“We’ve worked with a lot of the girls before and know the team has potential.“Right from the get-go the support from Aberdeen has been amazing. The video analysis, support from sport science, it’s more of a team project.“But we’ve been working a lot on our team strategy, the style of play and made sure the players are involved in that process.“The tempos have been great at training so far with their attitude.”With Division Onefootball comes games against other local sides like Cove Rangers and Buchan Ladies.Aberdeen in their old guise were always the top dogs of the women’s game in the north-east.How do they make sure this doesn’t change Hunter said: “There are a lot of good teams in the north-east, and players we know and have worked with.“No game’s going to be easy, but we’ll lay down our marker with a consistent, professional approach. Hopefully that shows on the pitch with our football.“We’ll go on the pitch with a plan and execute those plans.”Hamdani, who also has experience with elite youth development and coached Aberdeen FC Ladies’ Us last term, said: “It’s an extremely competitive squad full of youth national players capable of playing at a higher level.“That’s why our aim for this season is to gain promotion, so they can play at that level.“It’s a big expectation, but we’re looking forward to embracing the challenge.”Captain Kelly Forrest has been associated with the senior women’s team for nine years.The -year-old said the move to become part of the Pittodrie family was “exciting” after the disappointment of last season, where a poor start and points deduction for fielding an ineligible player crippled the team.She added: “There’s the natural things like sports science and physio access, plus the great coaches we’ve managed to bag in Emma and Harley.“Aberdeen are a massive club and their decision to take over the team is great for the growth of the women’s game.“Right from the word go they’ve made it clear what they expect and that’s for us to be big competitors in Scotland and get back to where we belong.”

title: the don who never was
story: With the transfer window closing tonight players across Scottish football will be trying to sort out a move for themselves as the deadline looms.To many observers a transfer may seem a relatively straightforward process – once a club wants you and the club you are at is happy to let you go, then that should be it.Not necessarily. In January , Aberdeen missed out on the capture of Jim McInally in extraordinary circumstances.The former Dundee United midfielder had fallen out of favour at Raith Rovers and a move to Pittodrie had been proposed.The Dons had offered the Kirkcaldy club former Stark’s Park midfielder Peter Hetherston in a straight swap for McInally.Everything seemed to be going according to plan, with McInally paraded at a Pittodrie press conference on January  .However, later in the day it emerged Hetherston had failed his medical at Raith and the deal was off.McInally, now manager of Peterhead, said: “I had fallen out with Jimmy Nicholl, who was Raith manager, and there was really no way back for our relationship.“He was taking the players away the week before Christmas to Magaluf but I refused to go.“I didn’t want to leave my two young kids because at that age Christmas week was a special week for the family.“When I refused to go that was me and Jimmy finished and he was desperate to get Peter Hetherston back at Raith because he was a hero at the club.“It was a dream come true for me really because it would have brilliant to go to a club of Aberdeen’s stature at that stage of my career.“To say it was long drive back down the road after that was an understatement – I was gutted.”In the - season, Aberdeen were enjoying a good campaign under Roy Aitken’s management.They had lted the League Cup in November and would end up finishing third in the Premier Division.For McInally, to this day there remains a sense of “what might have been ” over his move to the Granite City.He added: “It was a massive low for me what happened.“I hadn’t been in a situation before like I was with Jimmy at Raith and with the move not happening it felt like the rug was pulled from underneath me.“Going up to Aberdeen gave me a real lt and I remember being paraded at Pittodrie and doing the press conference.“Then I was supposed to play Cove Rangers in a friendly that night at Allan Park.“I was taken to a guest house and went for a sleep in the afternoon to prepare for the game.“Then I got a phone call from Roy Aitken saying Peter had failed his medical, so it was a disaster.“I was preparing to play the friendly that night and everything was fine at my end.“So for the move not to happen was a massive let-down.“It shows how things can go wrong with transfers and for me it would have been brilliant to play for a club like Aberdeen.“I was  at the time, so I was maybe past my best, but I was still fit.“Something like that hadn’t happened to me until near the end of my career and at that time there wasn’t transfer windows either, but the move still couldn’t be resurrected.“Now it must be a nightmare for playersthe window is coming closer to shutting and you can’t move and then are left in a situation knowing you’re not going to play.“It was a brilliant for me that day when I thought I would join Aberdeen.”

title: blind groups horror over cycle path plan
story: A blind group today slammed plans for a new Aberdeen cycle path, saying it will create a “no-go area” for people who suffer from sight problems.Sandy Taylor, Scottish representative for the National Federation of the Blind , said the proposed Dyce cycle route could present a danger.The new path will create a shared walking and cycling space as well as provide better links with the train station in Dyce.Under the plans, a .-metre shared-use cycle route will be created.Mr Taylor believes potentially having blind people and cyclists in the same area could be a danger.He said: “We’re not happy about it. I am completely blind so it’s not so bad for me, but there are people who are partially sighted, andall you can see is a shadow coming towards you it can be very scary.“These footpaths must be segregated. There must be a raised kerb between the path and pavement.”Mr Taylor said a similar scheme has been put in place in Kirkintilloch.He said: “They’ve lowered the kerbs and taken away all the courtesy crossings. It’s made the area into a ghost town.“It’s turned it into a no-go area blind people just avoid now.“And it’s something that looks to be happening in Aberdeen as well.”Mary Rasmussen, chairwoman of Guide Dogs Aberdeen, called the move “horrying”.She said: “It’s so frightening when there’s a shared space between pedestrians and cyclists.“I very much hope they will consult with people locally during the building process and they will speak to people in the local area in particular.“It’s great that people can cycle but there have to be some constraints.”The period for consultation on the cycle path closed on Monday and the NFB has submitted a representation against the plans.A spokeswoman for Aberdeen City Council said: “Views submitted as part of the online exhibition will be considered in due course.”

title: north east schools could have half day fridays in bid to tackle teacher shortage
story: A shake-up of school hours is being considered in a radical move to tackle teacher shortages across north-east.Newly released figures reveal there were  teacher vacancies across the region on January .Of those,  were in primary schools and  across secondaries.The figures have risen since September last year, when there were  unfilled posts, with a new report to councillors claiming the situation continues to be “challenging”.Education bosses at Aberdeenshire Council have put forward a raft of new measures, which could be looked at in the future, including the introduction of an asymmetric week for pupils.An asymmetric week means that instead of each school day being the same , four could be a little longer, with every school finishing earlier on one of the days.Schools in the Scottish Borders made the switch in , suggesting a Friday lunchtime finish would reduce staff costs and increase opportunities for e-learning and shared teaching.They also said it would allow for training and development sessions to be held during the pupil-free afternoon, allowing teachers more time in class rather than in meetings.Councillor Alison Evison, education spokeswoman for the opposition, said: “Teacher recruitment remains challenging in Aberdeenshire, due largely to geographical and economic factors.“There has been much creative work to address the issue but such work does require investment.“Previous budgets proposed by the SNP Labour and Communities Partnership have recognised this.“Any initiatives must be in conjunction with the teaching unions and should retain a focus on developing and supporting quality learning for our pupils.”She added: “Those of us living here know what a tremendous place Aberdeenshire is to live in and we must continue to promote it as a very welcoming place.”Other measures being considered include exploring ways in which teachers can access a mortgage support scheme, to allow them to secure housing in the area, and the use of bursary schemes to financially support those seeking to gain a teacher qualication.Work would also continue for the council to “grow its own” teachers including promoting teaching as a career to school pupils and making use of the BP Tutoring Scheme where Robert Gordon University students gain experience in schools.A report to members of the council’s education and children’s services committee said the shortages continue to be in primary schools in north Aberdeenshire, particularly in Banff, Fraserburgh and Peterhead.There are also shortages across Aberdeenshire for certain subjects, such as science, technical, maths and home economics.

title: staffies named britains favourite dogs and the scottish spca have two in aberdeen looking for a new home
story: An animal charity is looking for help to find new forever homes for #Britain#s favourite dogs#.A survey of , people conducted for a new ITV show found the UK is a nation of staffie lovers.The Scottish SPCA are looking to rehome  smiling staffies across Scotland, including two in Aberdeen.Naomi and Ruby, who are being looked after at the charity#s rehoming centre in Drumoak, are both looking for new homes after being with the SPCA for a combined total of more than  days.The charity#s longest staffie resident is Sandy, who has been at the Scottish SPCA centre in Ayr for more than  days.Scottish SPCA rescue and rehoming centre superintendent Sharon Comrie said: “It’s clear to see why they were announced as our favourite dog breed in the UK. They are friendly, loyal and affectionate dogs.#They are real people dogs and thrive on human companionship.“We currently have  super staffies in our centres across Scotland.#Some have been with us for more than  days.“Sandy, who is being cared for at our centre in Ayr, is our longest current staffie resident. He arrived over  days ago.” vw, px"  Sharon added: “Sandy is nine years old and has been with us since May . He’s playful and absolutely loves his toys.“He’s still a bit unsure of new situations, so he’ll need a patient owner to ease the transition into his forever home.“As much as we love him, we’re desperate to find him the loving family he deserves.“In addition to Sandy, we have  other staffies in our centres that are still looking for their ‘staffie ever after.’”

title: vintage cars leave aberdeen hotel on grand tour of scotland

title: coleman and aliyev impress ardrishaig
story: Robert LaceyUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs the lights dimmed in Ardrishaig Hall on Saturday January , and the audience chatter subsided, two young men, dressed entirely in black, strode into view.Jâms Coleman sat at the splendid Yamaha grand piano that for all visiting musicians must be such a relief to see, while Jamal Aliyev carefully set the spike of his special Giovanni Gabrielli Cello , an instrument re-discovered after a -year absence from public performance.Then the music began and the dark first notes of Beethoven’s Cello and Piano Sonata op. no. in G minor filled the hall. It was written for Count Friedrich Wilhelm, supposedly simplied for amateurs to play. However, Jamal and Jâms being master musicians showed the power of this often disregarded piece, to be immense. One of the first works to make piano and cello equal musical partners, it is full of ingenious dialogue between the instruments. The structure is unusual, but with such expert performers it delighted the audience who were moved by every turn and twist of this deeply emotional work.Jâms, from North Wales, after remarking on the three ferry crossings required to get to Ardrishaig via Bute, introduced the next piece, Ernest Bloch’s work ‘From Jewish Le’. In a style close to Jamal’s heart and heritage, having been born in Baku Azerbaijan, its three elements, ‘Prayer’, ‘Supplication’ and ‘Jewish Song’, are full of the pathos and sorrow felt by the Jewish nation and also full of the signature augmented intervals and minor key tonality of much of middle eastern musics. How beautully these pieces demonstrated the lyrical qualities of the cello. Jamal’s bow searched for all possible nuances of tone and dynamic as his instrument sang from its lowest notes to a seductive soprano register.The concert continued after the interval with a second Beethoven work. The audience may have noticed a minor kerfuffle at the piano as many pages were rapidly turned before starting. Would it be the ‘Seven Variations’ for cello and piano or the ‘Twelve’, both based on themes from Mozart’s Magic Flute  The ‘Seven Variations’ won, being on the theme from the ‘Pamina’ and ‘Papageno’ duet entitled ‘In men, who know the feeling of love’. This work exhibits Beethoven’s practised ingenuity in the iation form and brought a lighter mood to the programme.Jâms Coleman introduced the final work, Frank Bridge’s Cello Sonata. He told of the four years of torment for the composer as he struggled to express his feelings about the First World War, finally finishing the composition in . The adagio in the piece caused the composer the most dficulty as he struggled with ambivalence about his own pacist views. Jâms and Jamal dealt with the challenges of this complex work which tracks huge changes in the world of music composition that were under way at that time. Again, the lyrical powers of the cello came to the fore as did the virtuosic requirements heaped on the pianist. Despite its undoubted innovations, this piece generously reaches out to its audience. Bridge uses the new musical freedoms only when justied, being happy toto more traditional tonal stability in the lyrical sections.Fulfilled, but not overburdened by the weightiness of the final piece, the audience applauded Jamal and Jâms back to the concert room to perform the ‘Swan’ from Saint-Saens ‘Carnival of the Animals’ as encore. This piece so beautully confirmed the excellence of Jamal’s playing and the superb quality of his quite special instrument.PIC:Jamal Aliyev and Jâms Coleman. no_aJamalandJam

title: ayr blind swimmer takes water
story: NewsAyr blind swimmer takes to water to raise cash for charityAyr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN NewsFern is splitting her charity swim between Prestwick and Troon pools "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA blind swimmer has taken to the water in a bid to raise charity cash. Ayr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks. The -year-old is putting in the aqua miles at her favourite pools in Prestwick and Troon in the hope of raising more than pound. Fern, who lives with Bardet-Biedl Syndrome , is completing the challenge with the aid of her care team at Partners For Inclusion. She said: “I really enjoy my swimming and I come to the pool three times a week. “It will be tough to complete all these s and I’ve just started out – but I’m enjoying it so far.” BBS is a rare genetic disorder with symptoms including sight loss, obesity and reduced kidney . Like many other sufferers, Fern was also born with extra digits. The condition affects just one in , people across the world.   Sister Leigh, , said: “We’re all incredible proud of Fern and what she’s trying to achieve. “She was diagnosed with BBS at a very young age and her condition, particularly her sight, has deteriorated through time. “But she is never one to complain so this is typical of her attitude – she’s just determined to get out there and do something worthwhile.” Staff at Prestwick and Troon pools are helping encourage Fern during her bid, as she tackles up to  s at a time during each session. And the former Mainholm Academy pupil hopes to complete the marathon water trip while stacking up the cash for BBS UK. The charity provides support for those living with the condition and their carers. Leigh added: “It would be niceFern’s story going public could help with her fundraising effort. “She has her small group of friends and carers but it would mean the world to her to get support from further afield and raise as much as she can.” •To donate visit https:www.justgiving fundraising fern-walker

And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: selkirk-youngsters-tv-show-set-for-a-second-series
story: A SELKIRK starlet has taken centre stage in a childrens TV show.Nine-year-old Mimi Robertson landed a lead role in CBeebies series Molly and Mack last year.Filmed last summer, the first series of the programme hit screens in the autumn and proved to be so popular with its audience it has now been recommissioned for a second series.The programme tells the story of eight-year-old Molly and her -year-old brother Mack.During the summer holidays, Molly is being looked after by a reluctant Mack who runs a toy and record stall in an indoor market called the Big Hub.The series follows Mollyrsquos fun adventures with Mack, her friends and the community who work there.Dad Mark Robertson said: "Mimi got the role by chance really. A friend flagged up that they were looking for someone to do some voiceover work for a TV programme."She went for that and spent a day doing some voiceover work. The woman who was in charge of that asked her to go to the open audition for Molly and Mack."That was in December  and we found out after that she got the part of Molly."Filming for the first series predominantly took place in Glasgow. Mimi said: "It was hard work, doing really long days, but I really enjoyed it and I learned a lot. I had lots of lines to learn and had a tutor on the days when I was meant to be at school."I also loved the Big Hub where the show was set up because it is a very special place with all the cool little market stalls to have adventures in."I enjoyed doing the filming in North Queensferry for the titles, although it was a bit chilly so it was hard to pretend not to be cold!"I was a very comfortable playing Molly because she is quite similar to me. She is very energetic, always has ideas, loves adventures, and whenever therersquos a problem she always wants to fix it.Dad Mark added: "I was more overwhelmed that she was - she took it all in her stride. She had a ball - she loved it."Aside from the children it was a real veteran cast and crew who had been doing tv and theatre for years. Mimi would come home and tell me what shed learnt that day."Mimi added: "It was cool to have my questions being answered on how they make TV shows - I always got to see how the cameras worked, how actors spend their morning before they go on set and how they did all their hair and makeup."With the family based in the Borders and the filming taking place in Glasgow, the logistics of Mimi working in Glasgow proved to be a family affair. Mark said:"The whole family mucked in to make it happen. We are not a stage or theatre family so it was all new to us."Were really proud of her and what shes done, its been a lot of fun."And its not just Mimis family who have been supporting her in her new role as a television star.Mimi is a pupil at Knowepark Primary School in Selkirk and her classmates helped celebrate her success with a special screening of Molly and Mack.Mimi said: "My friends didnrsquot believe me at first because no one had ever done something like this, but once we started watching episodes in class they believe me and are super supportive about it."The second series of Molly and Mack will begin production later this year.Mimi said: "I was very, very excited and glad that there is another series coming because I will get to see all the cast and crew members again, like the producer and director and all the chaperones."Molly and Mack is currently on CBeebies every weekday at .pm and .pm.

title: ae-figures-show-increased-waiting-times
story: THE number of people waiting more than four hours at Borders General Hospitalrsquos AE department has increased signicantly over the past year, new figures reveal.Data published by the Information Services DivisionScotland, an NHS body which publishes statistics on NHS Scotland, show that the number of patients waiting for more than four hours to be seen by medical professionals has increased by nearly a third.More than , people waited for more than four hours in , which is a .% increase on the figures from .Furthermore, the number of people waiting for longer than eight hours has increased by %, and the amount of people waiting for over  hours has increased by %.However, the percentage of people being seen within four hours has also increased over the  months, from .% to .%, meaning that while the number of people of waiting longer than four, eight, and twelve hours has grown, the vast majority are still seen within four hours.Claudia Beamish, Scottish Labour list MSP for South Scotland, used the figures to criticise the Scottish Government: ldquoScottish Labour has been concerned about the pressures on health boards for some time and these staggering figures expose the scale of the challenge NHS staff face in delivering patient care and how badly they have been let down by years of SNP mismanagement of our NHS.ldquoIncreasing numbers of people waiting too long at AE reveals unacceptable pressure in other parts of our health service such as in social care and primary care.ldquoWe already know that staff do not feel they are getting enough support and that the level ofunfilled health posts is unsustainable.ldquoI have written to NHS Borders to understand more about the underlying reasons for these increases.ldquoMinisters set the health service targets for staff to hit and then do not deliver the support andresources needed. It simply isnrsquot good enough.Rachael Hamilton, Conservative MSP for Etrrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, also criticised the Scottish Government, saying: ldquoNHS Borders staff work incredibly hard to care for every patient, but there is increasing pressure on services due to the decisions of SNP ministers who have led NHS Scotland into a workforce crisis over the last  years.ldquoScotland is to get a poundbn funding boost from the UK Government as a result of more cash going to the NHS in England.ldquoWe need to see the SNP stop the grievance politics and use the money effectively to ensure we see AE properly staffed and managed.However, SNP MSP Christine Graham, who represents Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, pointed out that Scottish AE departments are performing better than their close neighbours, insisting: ldquoScotlandrsquos AE departments consistently outperform their counterparts in England and Wales, however, the health secretary has been clear that no one should be waiting longer than they need to for treatment.ldquoIn the Borders, the number of people waiting for less than four hours in AE has improved from .% to .% since January , meaning that NHS Borders are beating Scotland-wide targets.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos poundm waiting times improvement plan sets out action to improve clinical effectiveness and efficiency, increase capacity, and design and implement new models of care.ldquoThe Scottish Government also announced in the budget that poundm will go towards reducing waiting times.An NHS Borders spokesperson also pointed out that NHS Borders was beating the Scottish average, saying: ldquoWe work very hard to see people in a timely manner, and over the past  months we have managed to see an average of  out of  patients within the national four-hour waiting time target.ldquoDuring the same period, the national average has been  patients out of .ldquoWe recognise that health and social care across the country faced unprecedented challenges during winter   such as a long, harsh winter featuring lsquothe beast from the eastrsquo and high numbers of influenza and norovirus.ldquoThis did impact on NHS Borders and when we are caring for a high number of sick people who cannot leave hospital until they are well enough, it can take longer for us to see new patients arriving at our emergency department.ldquoThis is not what we would wish for the people of the Borders and we continually strive to improve our services so that we can provide prompt care to our patients.ldquoTo ensure our patients receive the right treatment from the right services we would encourage people to continue to keep the emergency department for emergencies by using their local community pharmacy, minor injuries units , and self-care when appropriate as well as phoning NHS  on  for advice.

title: cross-party-support-for-leadburn-improvements
story: POLITICAL pressure is growing for major improvements at a dangerous junction on the edge of Peeblesshire.Tweeddale MP David Mundell is backing calls for a roundabout to be introduced at Leadburn junction.And he is being supported by local MSP Christine Grahame.The convergence of A, A and A between Peebles and Penicuik has been the site of several fatal crashes and many other serious accidents over the years.And drivers continue to report near misses around the junctions.With Conservative councillors controlling much of the power in both Midlothian Council and Scottish Borders Council, Mr Mundell hopes progress can be made.He said: "Whilst there have been recorded accidents over the years, there are also many anecdotal accounts of near misses, which are, of course, not included in statistics used for prioritising roads spending."Although the junction is just outside my constituency, Ive been happy to raise the issue with the appropriate authorities because of concerns raised with me by many road-users I represent."The lack of progress so far has been frustrating but Im a great believer that in politics perseverance over a long period can be necessary to find solutions to challenging problems."Thats why Im giving my full backing to Conservative councillors in both Midlothian and Scottish Borders councils who will be campaigning for improvements at the junction."Just over  years ago the historic Leadburn Inn was totally destroyed in a fatal crash.And campaigning has continued following further accidents as well as continued near misses.Local MSP Christine Grahame has welcomed the support of Mr Mundell, but wants more than just words.She said: "The Leadburn Junction has been a source of safety concern for local residents for many years. Irsquod welcome any action to improve it, but ultimately this falls at the feet of Midlothian Council.ldquoMr Mundellrsquos support is welcome, but as his Tory colleagues share the balance of power in Midlothian Council I, and indeed local residents, will want to see these words backed up by real action to improve the junction.

title: do-you-want-to-run-the-great-tapestry-of-scotland-centre
story: ITS being hailed as the best thing to hit Galashiels in a generation.And you could soon be running it.Leisure and cultural charity Live Borders is looking for a centre director to look after Alexander McCall Smith, historian Alistair Moffat and artist Andrew Crummy, the Great Tapestry of Scotland tells the countryrsquos story through  , making one of the largest tapestries in the world.The new building which will house the Tapestry has been designed by one of Scotlandrsquos leading architectural practices, Page   Park, while the adjacent former Post Office will be re-purposed to bring the B listed building back into use.There will also be retail, cafeacute, educational and temporary exhibition space, as well as an ongoing events and exhibitions programme.Jane Hogg, commercial director for charity Live Borders, said: ldquoThe centre director role for this new visitor attraction, which is planned to open in spring , is a brilliant opportunity for someone with bringing the ,-plus visitors we want to attract to Galashiels, as well working in collaboration with the wider community we want everyone to be proud of this landmark project."The Great Tapestry of Scotland is a phenomenal achievement and this new visitor experience will celebrate the creative talents of the army of , stitchers, the story of Scotland, and its people it is a triumph of creativity, skill, community and patience."Work on the Tapestry building is due to begin this spring.The visitor attraction is seen as a catalyst for the regeneration of Galashiels.Experts predict that the centre will attract over , people to Galashiels each year once opened, as well as create  jobs.Almost pound, of extra spending per year is predicted for the local economy, providing , extra region.The closing date for applications is Friday, February .To request a an application pack email recruitment@Liveborders.org.uk quoting job reference .Interviews are expected to be held later in
